DIV1.P: As IT VVAS PRESEN∣ted by her Majesties Servants At the private House in Drury-Lane.
LONDON. Printed by IOHN NORTON, for ANDREW CROOKE, and WILLIAM COOKE. 1637.

DIV2.HEAD: Actus. I.
DIV2.STAGE: Enter Master Wilding; and Mistris Penelope.

SP.SPEAKER: WIld.
SP.L: What neede you be so coy now?

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: Pray collect
Your selfe, remember what you are, and whose
You have a vertuous gentlewoman, thinke
Upon your faith to her.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Thinke of a Fiddle-sticke.
While you put me in minde of what I am,
You quite forget your selfe: my wife I allow
Your kinswoman farre off, to whom a widdow
Your father left you, with a handsome fortune,
Which by her marriage, I have in possession,
And you too; therefore as you hope to be
In due time worth a husband, thinke upon't:
I can deserve respect, then wisely use me,
As you would keepe me.

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.L: This is but a triall
Of my strength, for I know you have more charity,
(Should I consent) then Ship-wracke your owne honor.
But take heede sir, how you proceede to jest
With frailty, least too much disordering
Your good thoughts, you forget and by degrees,
Loose your owne innocence.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.P: I jest? you'ld have me sweare, and yet you should not thinke it such a wonder: to love▪ come, shake off this frost, it spoiles thee; your nature should be soft, and flexible; perhaps thou thinkst, I doe not love thee hartily, I know not how to give thee better testimony, then by offering my selfe to thee if my wife-die, as tenn to one shee's not immortall, we may couple tother way.

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.P: What argument is this to assure the truth of your af∣fection to me, that breake your vowes to her?

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.P: Oh! great argument, and you observe: she was a wid∣dow when I married her, thou art a yong maide, and handsome.

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.P: Can you be so ingratefull, to punish whom you should reward, remember sir, shee brought you that wealth you have▪ tooke you from nothing —

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.P: Ther's reason then for nothing I should love her: hang her estate, I was held a proper man, and in that point, de∣serv'd her, and shee had millions: and I were free again. I would not draw i'th teame of marriage for ten not to command a Province.

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.P: Yet you said, were your wife dead you'd marry me.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.P: Onely thee, and no body else.

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.P: 'Twere dangerous to: have many.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.P: To have one, is little lesse then madnes; come, wo't promise? Enter Mistris Wilding.

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.L: What?

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: A course, you know my meaning.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.L: I doe not like this whispering, why with her
So close in parly?

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Wo't thou doe this feate for me?
'Tis finish'd in a paire of minuts.

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.L: Yes, upon one condition.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: What condition?

SP.SPEAKER: Pe.
SP.L: That your wife give consent, you shall then command me.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: I'le undertake to goe a pilgrimage
To Ierusalem, and returne sooner: wood
I did not love thee, love thee infinitely,
That's all, 'two not doe—My wife, I hope. Exit Pene.
Shee has not cav's-dropd, us; what pitty tis
She cannot finde the way to Heaven; I should not
Trouble her in hast, these wives will have no conscience,
But sticke to us everlastingly. Now Lady,
How did your monkey rest last night, you looke
As you had not done your prayers yet, I wonot disturbe you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.L: Pray sir stay, let me but know
Some reason why you use me thus unkindly?
If I have beene gilty of offence, I am not
Past hope, but with the knowledge of my error,
'Tis possible I may amend, and please you.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: I doe not like you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.L: You did marrie me.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi,
SP.L: Yes, I did marrie you; her's too much record for't,
I would there were a Parson to unmarry us,
If any of our Clergie had▪ that faculty,
He might repaire the old; and build as many
New Abbeyes through the Kingdome in a tweluemonth.
Shall I speake truth? I never much affected thee,
I married thee for thy soules sake, not thy body,
And shall as soone get children on't: and yet
I doe not hate thee, witnesse, I dare kisse,
Hold thee by the hand, and sleepe in the same house,
And in thy bed sometimes, something ha's beene done.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.L: Within the memorie of man, but—
What sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Wi
SP.L: You have a scurvy quality wife, I told you on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.L: Once more, and I'le correct it.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: You are given to be jealous, I cannot
Ramble abroad in gentlemens company
Whole dayes, ly out a nights, but you suspect
I am wanton, 'tis ill done, it becomes no modest
Woman: that loves her husband, to be jealous,
What e're she see, or heares, mend, mend this fault,
You doe not know, how it may worke upon me.
Some wife will bid her husbands leverets welcome,
Keepe house together, and provide cleane sheets,
And cullices to fortifie; you neere did it:
Know her owne Chamber and not come forth▪
Till she be sent for; if her husband kisse her,
Sometimes, allow her clothes and other trinkets,
Suffer her carve at Table, she is satisfied,
And none o'th parish talke, she carries it
So handsomlie: these moralls I have read
Before now, but you put them not in practise,
Nor for ought I perceive, have disposition too't,
Therefore i'le take my course.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.L: To shew I can
Be obedient to my griefes, from this time, sir,
I wonot urge with one unwelcome syllable,
How much I am neglected, i'le conceale it
Too from the world, your shame must needs be mine.
I see you doe not love me, where your heart
Hath plac'd a worthier thought, let it dwell ever,
Freely persue your pleasures, I will have
No passion that shall mutinie, you are,
And shall be Lord of me still.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: I like this, if it be no disguise.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.L: Do not suspect me,
I would sweare by a kisse, if you vouchsafe it,
You shall not keepe a servant, that shall be more humble▪

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: And obedient to my will?

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.L: In all things.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: But if I bring home a mistresse?

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.L: I'le call her sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: What if there be one
Already, that does please me, will you not
Repine, and looke awry upon's, when we
Make much of one another?

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.L: So you will but sometimes smile on me too, i'le indeavour.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Well said, this may doe good upon me▪ as
I finde you prompt in this, I may consider
Other matters: to tell you true, I love
Your kinswoman.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.L: How?

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: I'th way you wot on, but
I finde her cold and peevish, how she maie
Be brought about I know not, 'twould shew well,
And be a president for other wives,
If you would put your helpe too't.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.L: Goodnes blesse me.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: One woman with another can doe more
In such a cause, then twentie men. I doe not
Wander, you see, out of the blood, this will
Be a way to justifie your obedience.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.L: You shew a tyrant now, and stead of framing
My soule to patience, murder both. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: I have gone too farre a conscience; this may
Spoile all, and now I thinke upon't, I was
A coxcombe to discover any party,
I must deny't againe, and carry things
More closelie. How now Will? Enter Hazard.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: How now Will? 's that all?
Looke up, and aske me a question like ā man,
What melancholy?

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: No, no; a toy, a trifle.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: That should be a woman, who'st thou art thinking on?
I have beene of your counsell.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: I was thinking, o' my Wife—

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: I met her sadd.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: I cannot blame her;
We have had a dialogue; come, thou know'st my bosome,

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: when do'st meane to lie with her?

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: I know not, but I have offer'd faire conditions:
Shee is very confident, I doe not dote
Upon her beauty, I have told her, sirra,
I love her kinswoman.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Y'are not so mad.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: The worlds deceav'd in her, sheele give me leave,
To ramble where I list, and feede upon
What best delights my appetite.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: He that has
An ambition to be strangled in his sleepe,
May tell his wife he loves another▪ woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: But I was not content with this, because
The other wench was somewhat obstinate,
I must needs urge my wife, to mollifie
And mold her, for my purpose.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: And she consented too?

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: No 'twould not doe.
This went against her stomacke and we parted.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Next time you see her, looke to be presented
With your mistresses nose for this, do'st thinke a woman
Can be so patient, to know her rivall
I'th same roofe, and leave her eyes, to see thee
Agen? I am sorry for thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: I am confident
Shee dare not: but for all that, would I had
Beene lesse particular.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Come, I love thee well,
But not thy wit, to carry things no handsomer:
You must unravell agen, and make your wife
Beleeve you did but try her.
How now, what's the newes here?

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Off.
SP.L: Quickly to a Surgeon, beare him gently.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: What's the businesse.

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Off.
SP.L: Nothing, sir, but a gentleman is kild, and we are
Carrying him to a Surgeon.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Tis Jacke Delamore, he is not dead.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Who hurt him?

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Master Beamont; we cannot stay, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Why they were friends.

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Off.
SP.L: But wine made them fall out, some say, about
Their Mistresses.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: I did expect a woman at one end on't.
What miserable fooles are men, to kill
One another for these Cockatrices!

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: I am sorry for poore Beamont.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: It would be long ere any mistresse would
Be so desperate for her servant, this is valur,
High and mighty valor.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Men must preserve
Their honors man, thou dost not know their quarrell?

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.P: Thou art held a peece of a kill-Cow too, looke too't before the sessions take an order w'ee: ist not a great deale sa∣fer, now to skermish with a Peticote, and touze a handsome wench in private; then be valiant in the streets, and kisse the Gallowes for't? hang, hang this foolerie, let gentlemen rather live, and pay their Tailors, then let their clothes en∣rich the hangmans wardrobe.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: But skermishing as you call it, with the Peticote,
Is by some, held away to this preferment,
Your wenches beene sticklers, and some men
Dropt in their quarrell.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Let them be such coxcombs
They cannot die too soone; cannot I have
A Lady of pleasure, but to please her humour,
I must be engag'd to fight and kill men for her?
Because her healths refus'd, anothers nose
Or teeth preferrd, substantiall grounds for murder,
We spend our blood too much another way;
Consumption take me, if I fight for one on'em,
I will drinke single beere first, and live honest,
Gentlemen are come to a fine passe, doe not you
Thinke but tis possible, I may fight for all this?

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: There may be causes, that have women in'em,
But I confesse, no polecats, or Iewd strumpets,
Though I doe use the tricke o'th flesh, shall drive
Me to the Surgeon; I had a mother.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: And I have a wife, would thou had'st her.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: No, No, she is well as shee is,
There may be honor to defend these.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Sometimes.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: But ther's a mischiefe greater then all these
A base and sorded provocation,
Us'd among gentlemen, they cannot quarrell
About a glasse of Wine, but our files streigth
Sonne of a whore, dead mothers must be torne,
Out of their graves, or living, have their names
Poysoned by a prodigious breath: it were
A brave and noble Law, to make this tongue
Be cut for't, it wod save much blood ith yeere,
That might be spent more honorablie.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.P: The lie grew a dull provocation, this has quickn'd us, but leave this common place, thou canst not helpe it, letts talke of something else. Stay is not this Beaumont?

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Apprehended, alas poore gentleman; how now Ned?

SP.SPEAKER: Bea.
SP.L: As you see gentlemen, cald to my account.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: We heard a peece of the misfortune, but
Be not dejected, he may live.

SP.SPEAKER: Bea.
SP.L: I feare it.

Pray lead me where you please, alas. Violante! this newes will
wound thee too. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: I'le with him, and know the story.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Twill but trouble me
I can doe him no service, beside that,
I am engag'd to meete old Master Barnacle.
Whither, whither Gentlemen, with your swords drawne?

SP.SPEAKER: Acr.
SP.L: Doest not see a gentleman led to Prison?
Wee'le reskue him from the Offcers, come joyne with us:
We shall draw more to the cause.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: You doe not meane
this rashnes: hide your swords be advis'd better;
D'ee know his fact?

SP.SPEAKER: Lit.
SP.L: He has slaine a gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.L: They say he is not dead, the wounds not mortall.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: And will you make one past cure?

SP.SPEAKER: Acr.
SP.L: How do'st meane?

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Upon your selves, coole your hot bloods a little,
No mutuny my country men, remember,
If he recover that is hurt, the tother
Will come off well enough, without your volour:
Breath, breath a while, you may if you have a minde too't
Instead of reskuing, betray a gentleman,
And your selves too, to a danger.

SP.SPEAKER: Lit.
SP.L: He sayes right.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Tis scurvey wearing hempe, if you scape killing,
There be more butchers then sell flesh; and Citizens
Have no mercy in their Clubs, especially
When gentlemen have so litle wit, to bring
There heads to'th knocking downe, 'tis a revenge
They owe you for their wives, oh take heede mainely
Of these left handed Halberdiers.

SP.SPEAKER: Acr.
SP.L: Confound 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: How many will you kill with your bird-spit?
You have more leggs and armes at home, which makes
You valiant, i'le not pare my nailes to day,
And yet I love my friend, as the best on you;
You know I dare fight too, but in this cause
You must needs pardon me, I beleeve the stoutest
That now would seeme all fire, and sword, will goe
With as ill will to hanging, as another,
And will becom't as scurvily, take your courses.

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.L: I thinke 'tis better:

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: O'th two, to go to the Taverne, and be drunke
In your owne defence, a wench is not so dangerous
Nor the Disease that waites upon her.

SP.SPEAKER: Acr.
SP.L: What if the gentleman that's hurt should die?
Then ther's no hope for tother.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Lesse for you,
You would be guilty of his murther too,
And snatch him from the Law, why you may doo't:
Tis pity but the government should thanke you,
And if you scape the halter for't, it may be
Another man in time, may cut your throate,
And ther's one for another, paid in the blood.
Come be your selves, these are not acts of gentlemen,
Where shame, not honor must reward your daring,
Though we be wild, it followes not we should
Be mad out-right.

SP.SPEAKER: Lit.
SP.L: I was ever of his minde.

SP.SPEAKER: Acr.
SP.L: Come lett's to Taverne.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: I am for that coast, now I thinke upon't
I'le meete you at the new randevow within
This halfe-houre, I expect a gentleman
That has engaged my promise; i'le come t'ee
Ere you be halfe drunke.

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.L: Doe not faile.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Drinke Sack and thinke not on't, what should be
The busines that old Barnacle has desired
My conference? 'tis not to lend me money sure,
Hee's here.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Master Hazard.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: I was comming to you, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: I am fortunate to prevent so great a trouble,
There is a busines, sir, wherein I must desire your favour.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Mine? command it, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Nay i'le be thankefull too, I know you are
A gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: That should incline, you thinke
I am not mercenarie

SP.SPEAKER: Ba.
SP.L: I beseech you, sir,
Mistake me not, rewards are due to vertues,
And honor must be cherish'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: What's your purpose?
Pray cleere my understanding.

SP.SPEAKER: Ba.
SP.L: To be plaine, sir,
You have a name i'th Towne for a brave fellow.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: How, sir, you doe not come to jeere me?

SP.SPEAKER: Ba.
SP.L: Patience, I meane you have the opinion
Of a valiant gentleman, one that dares
Fight and maintaine your honor against odds,
The sword-men doe acknowledge you, the baylies
Observe their distance, all the swaggering pusses
Strike their top-sailes, I have heard 'em in the streets
Saie there goes daring Hazard, a man carelesse
Of wounds, and though he have not had the lucke
To kill so many as another, dares
Fight with all them that have.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: You have heard this.

SP.SPEAKER: Ba.
SP.L: And more, and more, mistake not.
I do not all this while acompt you in
The list of those are cald the blades, that roare
In brothells, and breake windowes, fright the streets
At mid-night worse then Constables, and sometimes
Set upon innocent Bell-men, to beget
Discourse for a weekes dyet, that sweare, dammes,
To pay their debts, and march like walking armories,
With Poyniard, Pistoll, Rapier, and Batoone,
As they would murder all the Kings leige people,
And blow downe streets; no I repute you valiant
Indeede, and honor'd, and come now without
More ceremony, to desire your favour;
Which as you are a gentleman, I hope,
You'le not denie me.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Though your Language
Be something strange, yet, bcause I thinke you dare not
Intend me an abuse, I wonot question it,
Pray to the point, I do not thinke, your come
To have me be your second.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar
SP.L: I am no fighter,
Though I have seene a fence-schoole in my Dayes,
And crackt a Cudgell, yet I come about
A fighting businesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: You would have me beate some body for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Not so noble Hazard, yet
I come to entreat a valiant curtesie,
Which I am willing to requit in money,
I have brought gold to give you paiment, sir,
Tis a thing you may easily consent to,
And 'twill oblige me ever.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Be particular.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Then thus you are not ignorant I have a Nephew, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: You have so.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: One that's like
To be my heire, the onely of my name
That's left, and one that may in time be made
A prettie fellow.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Very well, proceede.

SP.SPEAKER: Ba.
SP.L: You know or you imagine, that I have.
A pretty estate too.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Y'are held a maine rich man, sir,
In money able to weigh downe an Alderman.

SP.SPEAKER: Ba.
SP.L: I have more then I shall spend; now I come close,
I would have this Nephew of mine, converse with gentlemen,

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: And hee does so.

SP.SPEAKER: Ba.
SP.L: I'le not pinch him in's allowance,
The University had almost spoild him.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: With what?

SP.SPEAKER: Ba.
SP.L: With modesty a thing you know
Not here in fashion, but that's almost cur'd,
I would allow him to be drunke.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: You may, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Ba.
SP.L: Or any thing to speake him a fine gentleman,

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: With your favour, sir, let me be bold a litle
To interrupt you, were not you a Citizen?

SP.SPEAKER: Ba.
SP.L: Tis confest, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: It being a thriving way
A walke wherein you might direct your Nephew,
Why d'ee not breede him so?

SP.SPEAKER: Ba.
SP.L: I apprehend;
And thus I satisfie you, we that had
Our breeding from a Trade, cits as you call us,
Though we hate gentlemen our selves, yet are
Ambitious, to make all our children gentlemen,
In three generations they returne agen,
We for our children purchase Land, they brave it
I'th Countrie, begets children, and they sell,
Grow poore, and send their sonnes up to be Prentises:
There is a whirle in fate, the Courtiers make
Us cuckolds; marke, we wriggle into their
Estates, poverty makes their children Citizens;
Our sonnes cuckold them, a circular justice,
The World turnes round, but once more to the purpose.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: To your Nephew.

SP.SPEAKER: Ba.
SP.L: This Nephew of mine, I do love deerly;
He is all my care, I would be loth to loose him,
And to preserve him both in life, and honor:
I come to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Now you come to me indeede, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: What shall I give you, sir, to let him —

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: What?

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Pray be not angry.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: By no meanes.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: There is no such security i'th World,
I'le pay for't heartily.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: For what?

SP.SPEAKER: Ba.
SP.L: What shall I give you troth, and let him.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: What?

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Beate you, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Acr.
SP.L: How?

SP.SPEAKER: Ba.
SP.L: Nay do not, sir, mistake me, for although
I name it, caursely I desire it should be
With your consent, no otherwise; my Nephew
Is raw, and wants opinion, and the talke
Of such a thing, to beate a gentleman,
That all the Townes afraid of, would bee worth
In's credit, heaven knowes what, alas you cannot
Blame a kinde Uncle, to desire all meanes
To get his Nephew fame, and keepe him safe,
And this were such a way.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: To have me beaten.

SP.SPEAKER: Ba.
SP.L: Y'are i'th right, but doe not misconceive me▪
Under your favour, my intention is not
He should much hurt you, if you please to let him
Quarrell, or so at Taverne, or where else
You shall thinke fit, and throw a pottle-pot—

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: At my head.

SP.SPEAKER: Ba.
SP.L: Yes, or say it be a quart, still under your correction,
Onely that some of your acquaintance and
Gentlemen may take notice, that he dares
Affront you, and come off with honor handsomelie,
Looke her's a hundred peeces, tell, 'em i'th Ordinarie
Th'are weight upon my credit, play 'em not
Against light gold, this is the Prologue to
My thanks, beside my Nephew shall in private
Acknowledge himselfe beholding.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: A hundred peces! I want mony.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Right.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: You give me this to let your Nephew beate me.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Pray take me w'ee, I do not meane he should
By beating, hurt you dangerouslie, you may
Contrive the quarrell, so that he may draw
Some blood, or knocke you, o're the pate, and so forth,
And come of bravelie, this is all.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Well, sir,
You doe not meane, you say hee should endanger
My life or limbes; all you desire, if I
Mistake not, is to get your Nephew credit,
That being flesh'd, he may walke securelie, and be held
Valiant by gayning honor upon mee.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: You understand me right.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: I'le put it up,
Pray send your Nephew to me, weele agree.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Agree, sir? you must quarrell, and he must beate you, else, tis no bargaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Not before
We have concluded how things shall bee carried.

SP.SPEAKER: Ba.
SP.L: I must desire your secresie and—

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Heer's my hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: And ther's my monie.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Your Nephew shall be a blade.

SP.SPEAKER: Ba.
SP.L: Why ther's ten peeces more, cause you come off
So freely, i'le send him to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Do so, why this, if the Dice favour me may bring all
My Lands agen, be sure you send him, but
No words for your Nephews credit.

SP.SPEAKER: Ba.
SP.L: Mum— I thanke you heartilie. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Be there such things i'th World, i'le first to the Taverne,
There I am staid for, gentlemen I come,
I'le be beate every day for such a summe. Eixt.

DIV2.HEAD: Act. II.
DIV2.STAGE: Enter Mistresse Wilding, and the Page.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.L: Wher's your Master, boy?

SP.SPEAKER: Pag.
SP.L: I know not Mistresse.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.L: Come neerer, sirra, you are of your Masters
Counsell sometimes, come, be true in what
I shall desire, and I shall finde a time, for your reward.

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.L: How d'ee meane Mistresse?
We Pages meete rewards of severall natures,
This great man gives us Gold, that Ladie Gloves,
Tother silke Stockins, Roses, Garters: but
The Ladie, and Mistresse whom we serve in ordinarie,
Reserves another bountie, for our closenesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.L: I see you can be a wag, but be just to me, and secret.

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.L: As your Physition, or your looking-lasse;
That in your absence cannot be corrupted
To betraie your complexion.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.L: What private mistresses, does Master Wilding visit?

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.L: Who my Master?
Alas forsooth, d'ee thinke he lets me know?

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.L: Nay, nay dissemble not.

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.L: I hire a Coach
Sometimes, or so, but ride alwaies i'th boote,
I looke at no bodie but the passengers,
I do not sit i'th same box at Playes with him.
I waite at Taverne, I confesse, and so forth,
And when he has sup'd, we must have time to eate too,
And what should I trouble my conscience,
With being too officious, till I am cald for?
Tis true, he waites upon the Ladies home,
But 'tis so darke, I know not where they dwell,
And the next day we have new ones, las meere strangers
To me, and I should be unmannerlie
To Catechise 'em, if now, and then, there be
Any superuous cast waiting-woman,
There be so many serving men about her,
I cannot come to aske a question,
And how should I know any thing?

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.L: I see you are old enough for vice.

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.L: Alas forsooth,
You know tis ill to doe a thing that's wicked,
But 'twere a double sinne to talke on't too,
If I were guiltie; beside forsooth, I know
You would neere trust me agen, If I should tell you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.L: Thou art deceav'd, it shall endeare thee more.

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.L: I must beseech you
To be excus'd, my Master is my Master,
My feete are at your service, not my tongue,
I wo'd not forfet my recognizance,
And shame the tribe, Pages, and Mid-wives are
Sworne to be close.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.L: Hence thou old in vilanie,
But 'tis in vaine to chide, leave me, and bid
Mistris Penelope come hither.

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.L: Yes forsooth.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.L: I know not which way to beginne, to me
Hee has betraid he loves her, she is present.

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.L: Will you be sad still Cozen, why d'ee greeve?
Be kinder to your selfe, trust me, I weepe
When I am alone, for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.L: Sorrow and I
Are taking leave I hope, and these are onely
Some drops after the cloud has wept his violence:
Were one thing finish'd, I should nere be sad more,
And I cannot despaire to know it done,
Since the effect depends upon your love.

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.L: My love? tis justice you command my service,
I would I were so happie.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.L: Make me so,
By your consent to my desire.

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.L: Pray name it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.L: I onely aske your love, praie give it me.

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.P: My love? why doe you mocke my poore hart, which Poures all it has upon you? y'are possest of that alreadie.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.L: You examine not
The extent of my request, for when you have
Given what I aske, your love, you must no more
Direct it, as you please, the power's in me
How to dispose it.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: And you shall for ever,
I have no passion that shall not know obedience to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.L: Your love by gift
Made mine, I give my husband you, love him.

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.L: I alwaies did.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.L: But in a neerer way:
Love him as I doe, with a resolution
To give your selfe to him, if he desire it.

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.L: I understand you not, or if you doe
Suspect I cherish any lawlesse fame—

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.L: Thou art to innocent; be lesse, and doe
An act to endeare us both, I know he loves thee;
Meete it, deere coose, 'tis all I beg of thee;
I know you thinke it a most strange request,
But it will make fortunate.

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.L: Greife I feare
Hath made her wild, d'ee know what you desire?

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.L: Yes, that you love my husband: modestie
Will not allow me to discourse my wish
In everie circumstance, but thinke how desperate
My wound is, that would have so strange a cure,
Hee'le love me then, and trust me i'le not studie
Revenge, as other wives perhappes would doe,
But thanke thee, and indeede an act like this;
So full of love, with so much losse and shame too,
For mine and his sake, will deserve all dutie,

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.L: I have no patience to heare more, and could
I let in a thought, you meant this earnest,
I should forget I knew you; but you cannot
Be falne from so much goodnesse, I confesse
I have no confidence in your husbands vertue,
He has attempted me; but shall hope sooner
To leave a staine upon the sunne, then bribe
Mee to so foule a guilt; I have no life
Without my innocence, and you cannot make
Your selfe more miserable, then to wish it from me:
Oh, do not loose the merit of your faith,
And truth to him, though he forget himselfe,
By thinking to releeve your selfe thus sinfullie,
But sure you doe but trie me all this while.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.L: And I have found thee pure, be still preserved so,
But he will stragle further—

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.L: Cherish hope,
He rather will come backe; your teares, and prayers
Cannot be lost.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.L: I charge thee by thy love,
Yet be ruld by me; i'le not be so wicked
To tempt thee in a thought shall blemish thee:
But as thou would'st desire my peace, and his
Conversion, if his wantonnes last with him,
Appeare more tractable, allow him so much
Favour, in smile, or language, that he maie not
Thinke it impossible to prevaile at last.

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.L: This may ingage him further, and my selfe to a dishonor.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.L: It shall worke our happinesse,
As I will manage things; 'tis but to seeme:
A looke will cost thee nothing, nor a syllable
To make his hopes more pleasing, on my life
Thou shalt be safe both in thy fame, and person,
Will you doe this for my sake?

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.L: I'le refuse no danger, if I suffer not in honor,
To doe you any service.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.L: I have cast it
Already, in my braine, but doe not yet
Inquire my purpose, as his follie leades
Him to pursue you, let me know, and i'le
By faire degrees acquaint you with my plot,
Which built on no foule ends, is like to prosper,
And see how aptlie he presents himselfe,
Preethee seeme kinde, and leave the rest to me.
He shall not see me. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: How now cooze? was that
My wife went off?

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.L: Yes, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Let her goe, what said shee to thee?

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.L: Nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Thou art troubled.

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.L: Pray to your knowledge, sir, wherein have I
Done injury to you, or her?

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Has she abus'd thee?
I'le goe kicke her.

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.L: By no meanes, sir, I steale away your hart,
And meete at stolne embraces.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Does shee twit thee? i'le kicke her like a foot-ball,
Say but the word.

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.L: By no meanes thinke upon't, I have forgiven her,
You shanot sir, so much as frowne upon her.
Pray do not as you love me,
Wee may studie a more convenient revenge.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: How's this?
I preethee if she have beene peremptorie,
Which was none of our articles, let me instruct thee,
How we shall be reveng'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.L: Sir, I acknowledge
The groth and expectation of my fortune,
Is in your love, and though I wod not wrong her;
And yet to have my innocence accus'd
Is able to pervert it, sir, your pardon,
I have beene passionate; pray love your wife,

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: No, no, i'le love thee, indeede, indeede I will,
Is shee jealous?

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.L: You know she has no cause.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Let us be wise; and give her cause, shall's coose,

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.L: Sir, if it be a trouble to your House,
Your breath shall soone discharge me, I had thought
The tie of blood might have gain'd some respect.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Discharge thee the house? i'le discharge her,
And all her generation, thee excepted,
And thou shallt do't thy selfe, by this, thou shat;
Ha, she kisses with more freedome, this is better,
Then if my wife had pleaded for me, Pen,
Thou shalt be mistresse, woot? come thou shalt,
Shee's fit for drudgerie.

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.L: Oh, do not say so.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Then I wonot, but I love thee for thy spirit,
Cause thou woot be reveng'd, punish her jealozie
The right way, when 'tis done, I doe not care
To tell her, it may kicke up her heeles too, another way.

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.L: Tell her what? you make me blush.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: No, no, i'le tell no bodie, by this hand.
Stay I have a Diamond will become this finger,
Weare it, and let my wife stare out her eyes upon't.

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.L: I wonot take't on such conditions.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Take it on any; shee is come about.

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.P: Sir Master Hazard desires your company at Taverne, he sayes there are none but gentlemen of your acquaintance, Master Acre-lesse, Master Little-stocke, and Master Sell-away, the three Gamesters.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: He must excuse me.

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.L: As you love me, goe, sir.
Have no suspition that I wish your absence,
I'le weare your gift, and study to be thankfull. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Well, ther's no great hurt in all this yet;
The Tides not strong against me, no talke now,
Of wives consent, i'le not remove my seige,
Shee'le studie to be thankefull, shee's mine owne,
As sure as I were in her maiden-head,
Now to the Taverne boy, and drinke to the purpose. Exeunt.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Hazard, Acre-lesse Little-stocke, Sell-away, as in a Taverne. Drawers.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: More wine, is not this better gentlemen,
Then spitting Constables? you wod have fought now,
And had your braine-pannes open'd

SP.SPEAKER: Acr.
SP.L: Right noble Hazard,
Heer's to thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Let come boy, fill it me steeple-high,
I am in vaine of mirth, and I ha cause
As you shall see in due time gentlemen.
Master Little stocke thou art dreaming o'th Dice.

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.L: Hee's melancholie.

SP.SPEAKER: Lit.
SP.L: Who I!

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.P: I'le play the farrier then, and drench thee for the sullens▪ a health to all our Mistresses, we have had 'em single, letts shuffle 'em now together.
Master Acre-lesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Fi.
SP.L: Wilt please you Gentlemen to have a Song.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: You have not washt to day, go get cleane manners;
You raskall we have no wenches.

SP.SPEAKER: Fi.
SP.L: I see no bodie, sir, you have wash'd my eyes out.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: It is not necessarie thou should'st have any:
Fill mee agen.

SP.SPEAKER: Acr,
SP.L: This fellow wod ha t'other Cup.

SP.SPEAKER: Fi.
SP.L: I have had a Cup too much alreadie gentlemen. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Let it goe round, and then in hope you may
Looke double, i'le shew you a sight, I wonder
Jacke wilding Stayes.
Hee's come i'th nicke.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Save, save you gallants, may a man come i'th reere?

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Give him his garnish.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Y'are not Prisoners for the reckning, I hope.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: For the reckning? now y'are altogether gentlemen,
I'le shew you a wonder▪ but come not to neere,
Keepe out o'th Circle, whatsoever you thinke on't,
This is a hundred pound, nay, not so close,
These Picturs do shew best at distance, gentlemen.
You see it, presto—

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Nay lett's see't agen.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Like to your cunning jugler, I ne're shew
My tricke but once you may heare more hereafter,
What thinke you of this Master Acre-lesse, Master Little-stocke,
And Master Sell-away?

SP.SPEAKER: Acr.
SP.L: We do not beleeve 'tis gold,

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Perish then
In your infidelitie.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Let me but touch it.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: It will indure, take my word for't, why looke you,
For your satisfactions, no Gloves off,
You have devices to defalke, preserve
Your talons, and your talents, till you meete
With more convenient Gamesters.

SP.SPEAKER: Lit.
SP.L: How cam'st by it?

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Tha'dst little or none this morning.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: I have bought it gentlemen, and you in a mist
Shall see what I paid for it, thou hast not drunke yet:
Nere feare the reckning man, more wine, you varletts,
And call your Mistris, your Scolopendia
If we like her complexion, we may dine here.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: But harke thee, harke thee Will, did'st winne it?

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: No, but I may loose it ere I goe to bed,
Dost think't shall mustie, what's a hundred pound?

SP.SPEAKER: Sel,
SP.L: A miracle, but they are ceast with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Acr.
SP.L: And me too, come lett's drinke.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: No matter, how it came Will, I congratulate
Thy fortune, and will quit thee now
With good newes of my selfe, my coose I told thee on,
Is wheel'd about, she has tooke a Ring o'me,
We kist, and talk'd, time out a minde.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: I know it,
My Almanacke sayes 'tis a good day to wooe in,
Confirm'd by Erra Pater, that honest Jew too,
I'le pledge thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr.
SP.L: Master Hazard there are two gentlemen below,
Inquire for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: For me?

SP.SPEAKER: Da.
SP.L: One's somewhat ancient, I heard him call
The tother Nephew.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Say I come to 'em presentlie,
Gentlemen, I doe caution you before
To be faire conditiond: one of them, the Nephew
Is of a fierie constitution,
And sensible of any affront, let this
Character prepare him for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Bring him not hither.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: There is a necessitie in't, I wod not for
A hundred pound but entertaine him, now
He knowes I am here. Exit.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Master Hazard againe, with Barnacle, his Nephew, and Dwindle.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: This is old Barnacle.

SP.SPEAKER: Acr.
SP.L: One that is to fine for Alderman.

SP.SPEAKER: Lit.
SP.L: And that's his Nephew, I have beene in's company,

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.L: Is this the youth Hazard prepard us for?
How bussie they are?

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: You could not wish better opportunitie,
These are all gentlemen of qualitie,
I'le call him cozen first, if it please you,
To endeare him to their acquaintance.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: I'le not be a witnesse of your passages my selfe; these will report as much as I desire, sir, if you be beaten I am satisfied.

SP.SPEAKER: Ne.
SP.L: But d'ee heare Uncle, are sure you have made
Your bargaine wiselie; they may cut my throat
When you are gone, and what are you the wiser,
Dwindle be you close to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: I warrant you we shall do things with discretion,
If he have but grace, to looke and talke couragiouslie.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: He may be valiant for ought I know,
Howsoever this will be a secure way
To have him thought so, if he beate you soundlie.

SP.SPEAKER: Ne.
SP.L: I doe not like the company;
But I have drunke wine too, and that's the best on't,
We maie quarrell on even Termes, looke to
Thy basket-hilt Dwindle, and have a stoole readie;

SP.SPEAKER: Dw.
SP.L: I will give your worship a stoole.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: As I am gentleman, be confident
I'le waite on you downe, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: By no meanes, let him beate you to purpose, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Ne.
SP.L: Buy Uncle. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.P: Come, sir, pray gentlemen, bid my kinsman welcome: a sparke that will deserve your knowledge.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: His kinsman? you are welcome.

SP.SPEAKER: Acr.
SP.L: He has power to command your welcome.

SP.SPEAKER: Lit.
SP.L: If I mistake not, I have had the happinesse
To ha beene in your companie afore now.

SP.SPEAKER: Ne.
SP.L: Mine, sir? d'ee heare, what if I quarrel'd
With him first? 'twill prepare me the better.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Do as you please; that's without my conditions.

SP.SPEAKER: Ne.
SP.L: I'le but give him now and then a touch, i'le close
Well enough I warrant you, you beene in my
Companie, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Lit.
SP.L: Yes, and at the Taverne.

SP.SPEAKER: Ne.
SP.L: I paid the reckning then.

SP.SPEAKER: Lit.
SP.L: You came into our roome—

SP.SPEAKER: Ne.
SP.L: Tell me of comming into your roome,
I'le come againe, you are a superfluous gentleman,

SP.SPEAKER: Wil.
SP.L: How's this?

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Let him alone.

SP.SPEAKER: Lit.
SP.L: Sir, remember your selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Ne.
SP.L: I'le remember what I please, i'le forget what
I remember: tell me of a reckning, what ist?
I'le pay't, no man shall make an asse of me,
Further then I list my selfe, I care not a fiddle-
Sticke for any mans thundring, he that affronts
Me, is the sonne of a Worme, and his father a
Whoore, I care not a straw, nor a broken point
For you, if any man dare drinke to me; I
Wonot goe behind the dore to pledge him.

SP.SPEAKER: Acr.
SP.L: Why her's to you, sir,

SP.SPEAKER: Ne.
SP.L: Why there's to you, sir.
SP.P: Twit mee with comming into a Roome, I could—finde in my heart, to throw a Pottle-pot, I name no bodie, I will kicke any man downe Stayres, that cannot behave himselfe like a gentleman, none but a slave would offer to paie a reckning before me, where's the Drawer? ther's a peece at all adventures; hee that is my friend, I cars not a rush, if any man be my enemie, he is an idle companion, and I honor him with all my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: This is a precious humor, is he us'd to these mistakes?

SP.SPEAKER: Lit.
SP.L: Your kinsman gives him priviledge.

SP.SPEAKER: Ne.
SP.P: I desire no mans priviledge, it skills not whether I be kin to any man living.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.P: Nay, nay, cozen, pray let me perswade you.

SP.SPEAKER: Ne.
SP.P: You perswade me? for what acquaintance, minde your busines and speake with your Tailor.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.P: And you be thus rude—

SP.SPEAKER: Ne.
SP.P: Rude, sir, what then, sir, hold me Dwindle.

SP.SPEAKER: Dw.
SP.P: Are you readie to have a stoole, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Nay, nay, Will, we beare with him for your sake,
He is your kinsman.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: I am calme agen,
Cozen, I am sorry any person here
Hath given you offence.

SP.SPEAKER: Ne.
SP.L: Perhapps, sir, you
Have given me offence, I do not feare you,
I have knock'd as round a fellow in my dayes.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: And may▪ againe—

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.P: Be knock'd, a pox upon him, I know not what to make on him.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Let me speake a word in private, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Ne.
SP.L: I can be as private as you, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Strike me a box o'th eare presentlie.

SP.SPEAKER: Ne.
SP.L: Ther's my hand on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Nay, nay, gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Acr.
SP.L: Master Wilding.

SP.SPEAKER: Ne.
SP.L: Let him call me to account, the recknings paid.
Come Dwindle. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.L: I did not thinke the foole durst ha done this,
Tis a strange youth.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: You shall heare more to morrow.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr.
SP.L: All's paid, and you are welcome gentlemen. Exeunt.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: Why should not we two live together, being
So equall in our passions? oh Violante,
Our knowledge grew from children, and our loves
Allie us in our natures.

SP.SPEAKER: Vio.
SP.L: Tis▪ my wish
To dwell with thee, I never knew that woman
In whom I tooke more pleasure to converse with,

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: But I have a father, and remembring him
A sorrow steales upon me, to betraie
My hopes of blessing; for although hee love me,
And deerelie as he sayes, for Children must not
Dispute with fathers, he affects not him
In whom I place all thoughts that can delight me,
He loves not Delamore, and what to me
Is all the World without him? I shall never
I feare, have his consent to be made happie
In marriage, and this, although our thoughts
Reflect with equall honor on our lovers,
Makes the distinction, and concludes me miserable,
Thy will depends upon no riged parent,
Thy path is strew'd with Roses, while I clime
A ragged cliffe, to meete whom I affect.

SP.SPEAKER: Vio.
SP.L: Indeede, Leonara I much pitie thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo,
SP.L: I prethee counsell me how shall I wrastle
With my sad destinie, and yet preserve
My filiall obedience, I must loose
A father, or a husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Vio.
SP.L: Would I knew
Which way to bid thee steere, but lesson'd by
My owne affection, I would have thy minde
Constant to him thou loust, time may correct
A fathers harshnes, and be confident
If poore Violante have a power to serve thee,
She will forget her owne heart, ere prove false to thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: Oh my deare soule, I know't.

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.L: Oh mistresse.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: What's the matter!

SP.SPEAKER: Vio.
SP.L: This face betraies some miserable accident.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: Speake, and assure us, what disaster makes
Thy countenance so wilde.

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.L: A friend of yours—

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: Is sicke, is dead, what more? and yet I have
So few, I can spare none.

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.L: Is dead, sinee you appeare so fortified.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: Is my father living, and Delamore?

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.L: Your father is in health, but—

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: Staie, as thou wouldst preserve thy mistresse in
The number of the living.

SP.SPEAKER: Vio.
SP.L: How my feares increase!

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: Except Violante, whom I see
Enjoyes her health, I have no friend but Delamore,
I hope hee is not dead.

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.L: Your Delamore is dead. Shee faints.

SP.SPEAKER: Vi.
SP.L: Friend, Leonora,
'Twas indiscreetlie done to open sorrow
So like a torrent, Leonora; friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: Why dost thou call me from him? sure I was
Going to meete my Delamore.

SP.SPEAKER: Vi.
SP.L: Give not such
Beleefe to these sad newes, untill you heare it
Confirm'd, dist see him dead?

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.L: I did not see him.

SP.SPEAKER: Vi.
SP.L: Have comfort then, this may
Bee check'd againe.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: Would I could hope it.

SP.SPEAKER: Vio.
SP.L: Have more courage friend,
Didst heare the circumstance?

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.L: He was slaine they say.

SP.SPEAKER: Vio.
SP.L: Nay then beleeve it not, he was so innocent,
He could provoke no angrie sword against him.

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.L: I wish your confidence were not deceav'd,
The last part of my storie will concerne
Your faith, and sorrow.

SP.SPEAKER: Vio.
SP.L: Mine? in her I share
Too much, but prethee since thou hast not beene
Slow to wound her, let me know my affliction.

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.L: The generall voice is, Master Beaumont slew him,
Your servant Ladie.

SP.SPEAKER: Vio.
SP.L: Tell the generall voice
It lyes, my Beaumont prove a murderer?
And of his friend? he would not kill an enemie.

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.L: All I can say in proofe of this, I saw him
Guarded to Prison, pardon my relation.

SP.SPEAKER: Vio.
SP.L: If thou beleevest thy eyes abus'd thee not,
Thou might'st with one breath spoken 'em both dead,
For the survivor lives, but to give up
His life with more shame, all my comfort is,
I shall not live to see it, oh Leonora,
Who is most wretched now? let thou, and I,
The few dayes that we have to live, be friends,
And die in perfect charitie, I must leave you
To manage your owne griefe, I have enough
To breake my poore heart too. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: What Seas breake-in
Upon us? I that could have dyed within
A gentle wave, now struggle for my life,
My father?

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.L: What, it seemes you heard the newes,
Come let your sorrowes drie up, you may see
What 'tis to be so rash, when you chuse next,
You'le consult me, I hope; wipe, wipe your eyes,
Your teares are vaine, I could say more.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: What sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.L: They are more then he deserv'd, and yet tis better
Thou shouldst bestow thy teares upon his Funerall,
Then I sigh'd at thy marriage; come, Heaven has
Beene kinde in this divorce, preparing thus
Thy better fortune, and preserving mine,
I am sorrie for the gentleman that kild him.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: Oh Murderer.

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.L: You are a foole, and know not
His provocation: in my youthfull dayes,
I was not patient when affronts were offred me,
Nothing more deere to gentlemen, then honor.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: Honor in murder?

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.L: This was otherwise:
In my owne defence I would kill a family,
He shew'd his generous spirit, all the towne
Speakes noblie of him, pity him, and pray for him,
And were he not desertfull, by this time
The generall vote had hang'd him.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: Oh, my fate!

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.L: Tother a loose, and inconsiderate man,
Lost in estate, and would ha married thee,
To ha squees'd mine, 'tis better as it is.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: Good sir, be charitable to the dead.

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.L: Be you first charitable to the living.
Speake well, and thinke so too, you do not know
What benefit may follow, and how ere
Your womanish sorrow for the present may
So mist your eyes, they will hereafter open,
To see, and thanke my care.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: Indeede your language,
Pardon my boldnesse, sir, is darke and mysticall.

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.L: You have your wit to apprehend sometimes,
But 'tis not passion must excuse your dutie to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: I hope.

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.L: Your hopes may faile you if you doe,
Be obedient hereafter, if you please,
And love my directions

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: I'le not have
A thought shall disobey you, and if ever
I love agen.

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.L: If ever? why suppose
I should propound one to you, now i'th heate
Of this misfortune, can your heart be obstinate
To me, and your owne good?

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: This is too soone
A conscience, sir, before his blood be cold,
To whom I profest love, to like another?
The World would much condemne me.

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.L: Is the World
Or I to be prefer'd, this makes the act
Of your obedience perfect, and because
I'le have assurance of what power I hold,
This minute i'le preferre one to your thoughts,
Dispose your heart to love the gentleman
That now's in Prison.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: Whom d'ee meane deere sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.L: He that kild Delamore, Master Beaumont:
Doe not suspect I trifle, he is of
A noble house, of a faire expectation,
Handsome in every part.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: Shall not hee suffer
For the blacke deede alreadie done?

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.L: Compose
Your selfe to love him, i'le finde a waie how to
Secure his life, and bring him freelie off.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: Oh! consider ere you move to farr;
If having slaine my comfort, for I must
Give it no other name, call not your justice
To my revenge, yet let me not be forc'd,
To have a thought so full of shame to women,
That he should be my husband, 'tis a staine
Time nor repentance can wash off, I know
You cannot meane so cruellie, beside
I shall commit a sinne, foule as his murther,
Upon poore Violante, and rob her:
Their heart's love hath seald up i'th eye of Heaven,
'Twere sacriledge to part em, shee's my friend too,
One that will rather die then injure me.
And he will rather suffer, if he be
Noble as you professe him, then consent to
So foule a guilt.

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.L: Let me alone for that,
If he refuse this offer for his life,
Why let him die, i'le put him too't, consider,
In this I shall behold thy naked soule,
Be rul'd, and prosper; disobey, and be
Throwne from my care and blood, at better leasure
I'le tell you more. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: Has Heaven no pity for me?
What killing language doth a father speake?
Poore hart prevent more greife, and quickly breake. Exit.

DIV2.HEAD: Act. III.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: This humour does become thee, I knew when
Thou didst consider, what was offerd thee;
Thy sullennes wood shake off, now thou look'st
Fresher then morning, in thy melancholie
Thy clothes became thee not.

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.L: Y'are i'th right,
I blam'd my Tailor for't, but I finde now,
The fault was in my countenance, wo'd we had
Some Musicke, I could dance now, la, la, la, bra, &c,

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Excellent! and shee be a bed but halfe so nimble,
I shall have a fine time on't; how she glides?
Thou wot not faile?

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: This night—

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: At the houre of twelue.

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.L: But you must be as punctuall ith conditions
For my vowes sake, not speake a syllable.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: I'le rather cut my tongue out then offend thee,
Kissing is no language.

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.L: If it be not to loude;
We must not be seene together, to avoide
Suspition, I would not for a world my cozen
Should know on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Shee shall die in ignorance.

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.L: No peece of a Candle.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: The Divell shall not see us
With his sawcer eyes; and if he stumble in
The darke, there shanot be a stone ith Chamber,
To strike out fire with's hornes; all things shall be
So close; no lightning shall peepe in upon us,
Oh, how I long for mid-night!

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.L: I have a scruple.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Oh, by no meanes, no scruples now.

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.L: When you
Have your desires upon me, you will soone
Grow cold in your affection, and neglect me.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Why hang me if I doe, i'le love thee ever:
I have cast already, to preserve thy honor,
Thou shalt be married in a fortnight, cooze,
Let me alone to finde thee out a husband,
Handsome and fit enough, we will love then too.

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.L: When I am married?

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Without feare or wit
Cum privilegio, when thou hast a husband,
Dost thinke I will forsake thee Pen? 'twere pity
A my life, sweete, oh there is no pleasure
To those embraces; I shall love thee better,
And the assurance that thou hast two fathers
Before thou hast a child, will make thee spring
More active in my armes, and I tell thee,
Tis my ambition to make a Cuckold,
The onely pleasure o'th World: I wod not
Wish to injoy thee now, but in the hope
Of tother harvest, and to make thy husband
Hereafter cuckold, that imagination
Sweetnes the rest, and I do love it mainely, mainely.

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.L: Tis double sinne.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Tis treble pleasure wench;
But we loose time, and may endanger thus
My wife into a jealozie, if shee see us,
Farewell, farewell deare Pen. at night remember,
I wonot loose my sport for halfe the countrie. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi. Wi.
SP.L: Thou hast hit my instructions excellently.

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.L: I have made worke for some bodie, you have put me
Upon a desperate service, if you do not
Releeve me, I am finely served.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.L: All has succeeded to my wish, thy place
I will supply to night, if he observe
All the conditions, I may deceive
My husband into kindnes; and we both
Live to reward thee better, oh, deere cooze!
Take heede by my example, upon whom
Thou placest thy affection.

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.L: Master Hazard.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha
SP.L: Save mistresse Wilding.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi. Wi.
SP.L: You are welcome, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.L: He is a handsome gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Gone abroad?

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.L: I am not certaine, i'le inquire.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Your servant
Ha! this is the frostie gentlewoman, in good time,
I care not if I cast away some words on her,
And yet shees so precise, and over honest,
I had as good nere atempt her, your name is
Penelope, I take it Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.L: If you take it,
I hope you'le give it me agen.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: What agen?

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.L: My name.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: What should I doe wot?
No, no, keepe thy name,
How ere thou dost thy maiden-head.

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.L: Can you tell me
Of any honest man that I maie trust with it?

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: I'le tell thee a hundred.

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.L: Take heede what you saie, sir.
A hundred honest men, why if there were
So many i'th City, 'twere enough to forfeit
Their Charter; but perhaps you live in the Suburbs.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: This wench will jeere me.

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.L: I hope you are not one, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha,
SP.L: One of what?

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.L: One of those honest men you talk'd of so,
One to whose trust, a Virgin might commit
A maiden-head, as you call it.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Yes, you may trust me,
I have possest a hundred maiden-heads.

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.L: How long?

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Nay, nay; they are no commodities to keepe,
Noe fault of ours: truth is, th'are not worth
Preserving, some of your owne Sex acknowledge it,
And yet by your complexion, you have yours still,
Away with't, and in time.

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.L: Why you are modest.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Yave hit me Lady: come, i'le give thee counsell;
And more, i'le helpe thee to a chap-man too,
Besides what ere he paies for't, shall be at charge
To mold it of himselfe; how light thou 'lt be
Without thy maiden-head, dost not spoile thy sleepe
And breede the night-mare?

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.L: Who can helpe it, you
Gentlemen are such strange creatures, so unnaturall,
So infinitilie chast, so mortified
With Beefe and Barly-water, such strange discipline,
And Haire-cloth.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Who weares Haire-cloth? gentlewoman?

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.L: Such severe waies to tame your flesh, such friends
To fry-dayes, Lent, and Ember-weekes; such enemies
To Sacke, and marrow-Pies, Candles, and Crabs,
Fidlers, and other warme restoratives,
A handsome woman can not reach your pity,
SP.P: We may e'en grow to our Pillowes, ere you'le comfort us; this was not wont.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Not wont to be, in my
Remembrance Ladie.

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.L: You are a handsome gentleman
Why may not you drinke Wine sometimes, or eate
Sturgion, or forrage in your Iustie-pie
Of Aartichoke, or Potato; or why may not
Your learned Physition Dictate amber-Greece,
Or Powders, and you obey him, in your Brothes?
Have you so strange antipathy to women?
To what end will gentlemen
Come to, if this frost hold?

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: You are wittie▪
But I suppose you have no cause of such
Complaint, how ever some men do want heat,
Their is no generall winter; I know a gentleman
Can drinke, and eate, and beare you companie
A bed, for all your jeering: do not thinke
Tis I: thou shall recant this prophane talke
And wooe me for a kisse, ere i'le stoope to thee.
Heres none but friends, if Master wilding ha not
Told you alreadie, I will justifie
Tis possible, you may be got with Child.

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.L: By whom?

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: By him, you are but cozens a farre off,
If you allow't, he neede not travell farre
For other dispensation, what say to him?

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.L: Was this at his entreatie?

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: My owne meere motion
And good will toward him, cause I know his minde.

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.L: You are a fine gentleman, wher's your land?
You may be Knight o'th Shire in time: farrewell, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: I know not what to make on her, she may be Exit.
A tumbler, for all this, i'le to her agen. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Ba.
SP.L: Nay, nay, be comforted, and mistake me not,
I did not mention Delamore to provoke
These teares: hee's gone, thinke on your living friends.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: If you be one, good sir—

SP.SPEAKER: Ba.
SP.L: Yes, I am one:
And yet mistake me not, I doe not come
Awooing for my selfe, I am past Tilting,
But for my Nephew, oh that Nephew of mine!
I know Sr. Richard Hurry, you wise father,
Will thinke well of him,
Nay, nay, weeping still.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: It is too soone to thinke of any other.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: To soone to thinke of any other, why,
What woman of discretion, but is furnish'd
With a second husband ere the first be coffend?
He that stayes till the Funerall be past,
Is held a modest coxcombe, and why should not
Maides as early in their provision?

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: I blush to thinke, my father of his mind,
Distressed Leonora good. sir loose
No more breath, I am resolved to die a Virgin
I know not what love is.
And yet these teares
Are shed for one you lov'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: He that was all
My treasure living, beeing lost must needs
Be a great part of sorrow: but my eyes
Though they can never paie to many drops
To the sad memory of Delamore,
Shed not all these for him, there is another
That makes me weepe.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Another whom you love?

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: Heaven knowes I never let into my heart,
Affection to a second, I am so farre
From loving him, I wish we may nere meete,
I am not safe in my owne bosome, while
I thinke upon him, it begets new springs
Within my eyes; which will in litle time,
Rise to a flood, and drowne me.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: I conceive
This is no friend of yours, come i'le releeve you,
Nay, and there be any man that troubles you,
If there be any you'd have talk'd withall,
I'le rid you of that care, he that shall offer
But to disturbe you in a thought, d'ee marke me?
I'le take an order with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: What will you doe?

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Do not mistake me neither, i'le do nothing,
But send my Nephew, he shall top him,
And top him, and scourge him like a top too.
You know not how my Nephew is improv'd
Since you last saw him, valiant as Hercules,
He has knock'd the flower of Chivalry, the verie
Donzal del Phebo of the time. and all
The blades do reverence him; i'le say no more,
Name but the man whom you do frowne upon,
And let me send my Nephew to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: Shanot neede.
I have no enemie to engage his sword,
My discontents flow from a neerer person,
I grieve to say my father.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: How? your father
Say but the word and I will send my Nephew
To him, and he were ten fathers he can mollifie him,
To please you Lady, my Nephew never spare him,
Oh, had you seene him baffle a squire this morning!

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: Pray no more, you shall do me a noble office.
To leave me to my selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.L: Mistresse Violante
Is come to visit you.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: I waite upon her,
Your gentle pardon. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Ba.
SP.L: Would my Nephew had her.
Shee is S. Richards heire, and here he is.
S. Richard?

DIV2.STAGE: Enter S. Richard Hurry, and Surgeon.

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.L: Oh Master Barnacle, i'le waite upon you.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: That's Master Probe the Surgeon.

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.L: No more you know my meaning.

SP.SPEAKER: Pr.
SP.L: Yes, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.L: Let him be buried.

SP.SPEAKER: Pr.
SP.L: I understand you, sir. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: I have beene discoursing
With your faire daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.L: Where is Leonora?

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.L: Shee's within, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.L: Bid her come hither,
Master Barnacle I am something troubled about a gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: And I am glad I met with you:
If you be troubled with any gentleman,
I'le send my Nephew to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.L: To whom, or whither?

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: To any man alive, I care not whether.

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.L: Send him to Jerusalem.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: That's something o'th furthest, I shall be
Unwilling he should travell out o'th Kingdome.

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.L: Leonera? Neerer—

SP.SPEAKER: Ba.
SP.L: Who is that?
A prettie gentlewoman! save you mistresse,
What is your name I pray?

SP.SPEAKER: Vio.
SP.L: I am cal'd Violante.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Are you a maide?

SP.SPEAKER: Vio.
SP.L: I should be sorrie else.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: D'ee know my Nephew?

SP.SPEAKER: Vio.
SP.L: Not I, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Not my Nephew? how have you beene bred?
Why hee's the onley gallant o'th Towne,
Please you i'le send him to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Vio.
SP.L: What to doe, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Ba.
SP.L: He shall do any thing, the townes afraid on him.

SP.SPEAKER: Vio.
SP.L: Oh! praie keepe him from me then.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Hee'le hurt no women, but for the men—

SP.SPEAKER: Vio.
SP.L: Ther's one has hurt to much alreadie.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: What is he? i'le send my Nephew to him Lady,
If you have any occasion, never spare him.

SP.SPEAKER: Vio.
SP.L: Not I, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.L: Looke to't, and correct this humor.
I'le to him presentlie, Master Barnacle,
Let me intreat your companie to a gentleman,
I'le waite as much on you.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: You shall command mee:
If't be to any man you care not for,
Wee'le take my Nephew along. Exeunt

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.L: It sha not neede,

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: Oh Violante! I
Must now require some fruite of all thy promises.

SP.SPEAKER: Vio.
SP.L: You hold me not suspected.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: Leonora
Cannot be so ingratefull: but we have
Small limit for discourse, my father meanes
To visit Beaumont, now in Prison, thou
Wilt heare too soone the storie, and without
Prevention finde thy selfe more miserable.
Oh Violante: I will suffer with him
Rather then injure thee, I prethee go
Uisit thy friend, not mine, and as thou lou'st mee,
As thou lou'st him, or thy owne life, Violante,
Bid him be constant to thee, tell him what fame
Dwells upon noble lovers, that have seal'd
Faith to their Mistresses in blood: what glorie
Can perjur'd men expect, that loose their honor
To save a poore breath? bid him be assur'd,
If for the hope of life, his soule can be
So much corrupted to embrace a thought
That I shall ever love him—

SP.SPEAKER: Vio.
SP.L: You Leonora?

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: Never, oh, never; tell him so: by vertue,
And the cold blood of my slaine Delamore,
Although my father threaten death.

SP.SPEAKER: Vio.
SP.L: Your father?

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: Make hast sweete Violante, to the Prison;
There thou shalt know all, there thou shalt have proofe
How much thou art belov'd, and by my death,
If he prove false to thee, how much I love thee. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Vio.
SP.L: I am amaz'd, and my soule much distracted
Twixt griefe, and wonder, it growes late i'th morning,
I le visit the sad Prisoner, my hart trembles,
More can but kill me too, I'm, fit to die,
And woes but hasten immortality. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: How now? what Gamesters?

SP.SPEAKER: Bo.
SP.L: Little to any purpose yet, but we
Expect deepe play to night.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Will Hazard, I have beene seeking thee this
Two howers, and now I have found thee, avoide me.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Thar't not infectious.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: No, but I swell with my imaginations
Like a tall Ship, bound for the fortunate Ilands;
Top, and Top-gallant, my flags, and my figaries
Upon me with a lustie gale of winde
Able to rend my sailes, I shall o'rerunne,
And sinke thy little Barke of understanding
In my careere boy.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Pray heaven rather
You do not spring a leake, and forfit your
Ballast, my confident man of Warre, I
Have knowne as stout a Ship beene cast away
In sight o'th Harbour.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: The wench, the wench boy.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: The Vessell you have beene chasing.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Has strooke Saile,
Is come in, and cries abord my new Lord of
The Mediterranean, we are agree'd,
This is the pretious night Will; twelve the hower;
That I must take possession of all,
Of all; there are some Articles agreed on.
Whoe's this?

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Oh! the Gamesters now come in:
That gaie man is a Lord, and with him Sell-away.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: They are well coupled, a Lord and Sell-away.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: He weares good clothes you see, and in the street
More look'd at then the Pageants, he will talke litle.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: To purpose.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Right, he cannot walke
Out of his sincopace, and no man carries
Legs more in tune, he is danc'd now from his sempstresse.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: A man much bound to his Tailor.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: And his Barber.
He has a notable head.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Of haire thou mean'st.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Which is sometime hung in more Bride-laces
Then well would furnish out two Country weddings

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Is he a Scholler?

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Tis not necessary.
He is neither Scholler, nor a Courtier,
If report wrong him not.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: VVill. He playes mony freely.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: With more pride then he weares embrodery.
Tis his ambition to loose that: and
A wench mainetaines his swearing, let him passe.

SP.SPEAKER: VVi.
SP.L: What's next.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: A Knight, and Acre-lesse.

SP.SPEAKER: VVi.
SP.L: Good agen, a Knight and Acre-lesse, what's his condi∣tion.

SP.SPEAKER: VVi.
SP.L: A Gamester both waies.

SP.SPEAKER: VVi.
SP.L: Where be his Spurres?

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Hang in his mistresses Peticote, for which hee pawnd
His Knight-hood too, till a good hand redeeme it,
He will talke you nothing but postilions
Embroideries for his Coach, and Flanders Mares:
What severall sutes for the twelue dayes at Christmas,
How many Ladies dote upon his physnomy:
That hee is limited but a hundred pound
A month for diet, which will scarce maintaine him
In Phesant egges an Turky for his motion.
Now does his Barge attend him, if he came
By water, but if the Dice chance to runne counter,
He stayes till twelue in anger, devours smoke,
And desperately will shoot the Bridge at midnight
Without a waterman.

SP.SPEAKER: VVi.
SP.L: The house fills a pace
What are these ha?

DIV2.STAGE: Enter a Countrie gentleman, and Little-stocke.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: A Countrie gentleman, and Little-stocke.

SP.SPEAKER: VVi.
SP.L: A Countrie gentleman? I have seene him sure
Appeare in other shape, is he a Christian?

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Why? dost thou doubt him?

SP.SPEAKER: VVi.
SP.L: Cause I have met him with a Turbant once,
If I mistake not, but his linnen was not
So handsome altogether as the Turkes
In quirpo with a Crab-tree cudgell too,
Walking and canting broken Dutch for farthings.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: The apparition of an Angell once
Brought him to this.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Dost call him countrie gentleman?

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: His generation is not knowne i'th Towne,
You see what Dice can do, now hee's admir'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: For what I prethee?

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: For talking non-sense, when he has lost his mony
You shall meete him going up and downe the ordinary
To borrow monie upon his head.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: His head,
Will he goe upon his head, or will he pawne it?

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Pawne it, if any man will lend him mony on't,
And sayes 'tis good securitie, because
He cannot be long without it, they shall have
The wit for the use too, he will talke desperatelie,
And sweare he is the father of all the Bulls
Since Adam, if all faile he has a project
To print his jests.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: His Bulls you meane,

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Y'are right,
And dedicate 'em to the Gamesters, yet he will
Seeme wise sometimes, deliver his opinions
As on the Bench: in beere he utters sentences,
And after Sacke Philosophy.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Let's not be troubl'd with him, who are these?
Yong Barnacle?
Will you indure him.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.P: Yes, and the Vineger-bottle his man too: but now I thinke on't he shall excuse me, i'le loose no time; if I winne, I shall have lesse cause to repent, if I loose, by these hilts i'le make him the cause and beate him.
Are they at play?

SP.SPEAKER: Sel,
SP.L: Deepe, deepe Gamesters.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Then luke with a hundred peeces.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.P:
I'le follow, how now Franke? what in the name of folly
is hee reading?

SP.SPEAKER: Ne.
SP.L: Save you gentlemen, save you noble gallants:
May a man loose any monie? I honor, sir, your shadow.

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.L: This is another humor.

SP.SPEAKER: Ne.
SP.L: D'ee here the newes gentlemen?

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: What newes I pray?

SP.SPEAKER: Ne.
SP.L: The new Curranto.

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.L: Good, sir, impart.

SP.SPEAKER: Ne.
SP.L: Be there no more gentlemen to heare it
Here? 'tis extraordinarie fine newes, in blacke and white,
From Terra incognita.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Terra incognita?

SP.SPEAKER: Ne.
SP.L: I, sir, the quintessence of the World: for our foure parts
Europe, Asia, Affricke, and America, are as the foure
Elements, and this, as the learned Geographers say, is
Like Coelum, a fift essence or quintessence of the World.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Pray, Sir, what newes from this quintessence, it must
Needs be refin'd novelties.

SP.SPEAKER: Ne.
SP.L: From Slavonia.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: That's no part of Terra incognita, we know that.

SP.SPEAKER: Ni.
SP.L: But you doe not know that Slavonia I meane, 'tis
Inhabited by a Nation without a head.

SP.SPEAKER: Dwi.
SP.L: Without a head in? what part are their eyes?

SP.SPEAKER: Ne.
SP.L: Peace Dwîndle: a cursed kinde of people that have
Neither Law, nor Religion but for their owne purposes:
Their Country is somewhat low, and open to the Sea.

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.L: Do they not feare drowning?

SP.SPEAKER: Ne.
SP.P: They are safest in a tempest, if they be taken at any time by their enemies, and cast over-bord, they turne other creatures, some Rocks, some Sharkes, some Crocadiles, and so retaine part of their former nature.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: What do those that dwell ashore?

SP.SPEAKER: Ne.
SP.L: They follow their worke, and make nets not only to catch
Fish, but Townes and Provinces: the Jewes
Are innocent to 'em, and the Divella dunce, of whose
Trade they are.

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.L: A dangerous generation.

SP.SPEAKER: Ne.
SP.L: In Perwiggana a fruitfull Country, the moone shines
All day, and the Sunne at night.

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.P: That's strange, hee has a morall in't have not wee gentlemen that sit up all night a drinking, and go to bed when the sunne rises?

SP.SPEAKER: Ne.
SP.P: In this Province the King never comes out of his Palace.

SP.SPEAKER: VVi.
SP.P: How does the Court remove there?

SP.SPEAKER: Ne.
SP.P: When he does purpose to change the aire, hee has an Elephant richly trapped, that carries the Court upon his backe into what part of the Kingdome he please.

SP.SPEAKER: VVi.
SP.P: I have heard of Elephants, that have carried Castles.

SP.SPEAKER: Ne.
SP.P: Snailes, Snailes in comparison: and to increase your won∣der▪ this beast does never drinke.

SP.SPEAKER: VVi.
SP.P: I would be loth to keepe him companie.

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.P: How then?

SP.SPEAKER: Ne.
SP.P: Eate, eate altogether, and what nothing but men, and of what ranke or condition, none but great men, and the fat∣test nobilitie, but like your good Mounsieur hee cares for no∣thing but the head, and it is confidently reported hee has devoured more heads, within this three last yeeres, then the Elephant wee had in England; eate Pennie Loves in sea∣ven.

SP.SPEAKER: Dwi.
SP.P: The Divell choke him would hee had London Bridge in his bellie too.

SP.SPEAKER: Ne.
SP.P: The subjects of the great Duke of Lubber-land ha's beene lately in rebellion.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.P: I am sorry it will be inconvenient to heare out your Cur∣ranto, I am weary of a little monie when that's lost I may bee a sutor for the rest of your newes, and so I commend mee to all your friends in Lubber-Land. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Ne.
SP.P: Dwîndle, didst heare this, now could I be angry.

SP.SPEAKER: Dwi.
SP.P: Goe to play then, sir, if you loose your monie, you may talke roundly to 'em for they cannot bee so uncivill as not to give loosers leave to speake.

SP.SPEAKER: Ne.
SP.P: But if I winne.

SP.SPEAKER: Dwi.
SP.P: Why then you may be drunke to night and i'le—the Caster to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lit.
SP.L: A curse upon these reeling Dice, that last in, and in
Was out of my way ten peeces; canst lend me any
Monie, how have the cards dealt with thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Acr.
SP.L: Lost, lost— I defie thee, if my Knight recover not
I must be sober to morrow.

SP.SPEAKER: Lit.
SP.L: Oh, for a hundred and all made now.

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.L: Yonders—winnes tirannically, without
Mercie, he came in but with hundred peeces.

SP.SPEAKER: Lit.
SP.L: I'le get a fancy presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Acr.
SP.L: And how thrive the bones with his Lordship

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.P: His Lordships bones are not well set they are malicious∣ly bent against him they will runne him quite out of all.

SP.SPEAKER: Ne.
SP.P: More mony Dwindle call my Uncle: I must have it, for my honor, two hundred peeces more Will serve my turne; in the meane time I will play away my Cloke and some su∣perfluous things about me.

SP.SPEAKER: Dwi.
SP.P: By that time you are come to your shirt, I shall bee here.

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.P: Hee's blowne up too. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.P: So, so, the Dice in two or three such nights will be out of my debt, and I may live to be a land-lord agen.

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.P: You are fortunes minion Master.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: You wod seeme to be no foole, because she dotes not
Upon you gentlemen, I must take my chance; 'twas
A lucky hundred pown'd Jacke Wilding.
What eating the Boxes.

SP.SPEAKER: Acr.
SP.L: Let us in agen.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Chewing thy cud a litle, I have lost all my monie Will
Thou hast made a fortunate night on't wot
Play no more.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Tis the first time I had the grace to give off a winner
I wonot tempt the Dice.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: What hast wonne?

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: You doe not heare mee complaine
I have not been so warme
This tenn weekes.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.P: Tis frost in my breeches.

SP.SPEAKER: Acr.
SP.P: Master Hazard, I was afraid you had beene gone, there's a fresh Gamester come in with his pockets full of Gold; he dazeles the Gamesters, and no man has stocke to play with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.P: What is he?

SP.SPEAKER: Acr.
SP.P: A Merchant he seemes; he may be worth your retire.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.P: Not for the Exchange to night, I am resolv'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.P: Temptation! now have I an infinite itch to this Merchants peeces.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: If thou wot have any monie,
Speake before I launch out, and command it.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.P: A hundred peeces.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.P: Call to the Master o'th house by this token—thou wot venture agen then?

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.P: They may prove as luckie as thine—but what do I for∣get? the wench, the fairy at home, that expects me.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.P: I had forgot too, you wonot play now.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.P: Tis now upon the time.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.P: By any meanes goe.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.P: Hum, I ha lost my monie, and may recover a prety wench. which hand? here covetousnes, this letchery; monie is the hea∣vier. Will, dost heare? i'le requite thy curtesie. Thou hast lent me a hundred pownd, i'le pay thee agen, and thou shat have for the use, the flesh device at home that expects, thou shat sup∣ply my place Will.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.P: You wonot loose this opportunitie, and foole your selfe. Exit. Acre.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.P: I am resolv'd; five hundred peeces say i'le come to him, you love the sport as well as I: to morrow you shall thanke me for't; be secret, shee'le never know thee, for our conditions are to—Neither light nor—and she must needs conceive tis I.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.P: Are you in earnest?

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Have you wit to apprehend the curtesie?
Let me alone: the wench, and I shall meete
Hereafter and be merry, here's my Key
The Merchants monie cooles away: be wise
And keepe conditions to use her at thy pleasure,
There will be enough for me: nay no demurres,
You have not lost your stomacke to this game
How ere I speed tonight, wee'le laugh to morrow
How the poore wench was cosen'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: But wouldst ha mee goe?

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
