SP.L: I wod ha thee ride boy, I must to the Gamester
Farewell, remember not to speake a word, but
Kisse and embrace thy belly full.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: If I do not,
The punishment of an Eunuch light upon me.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: How now Will, thou lookst desperatly this morning.
Didst sleepe well to night?

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Yes, 'tis very like
I went to sleepe; but such a bed-fellow!

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: What ailes she; was she dull?

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Do not enquire
But curse your selfe till noone, I am charitable
I do not bid thee hange thy selfe, and yet
I have cause to thanke thee, I would not have lost
The turne, for all the monie I wonne last night Jacke,
Such a delicious thieft.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: I thinke so.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: I found it so and dare make my affidavit.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Thou didst not see her?

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Nor speake to her, to what purpose.
Shee was so handsome i'th darke, you know
My meaning, had beene pittie any light
Or voyce should interrupt us.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Now doe I
Grow melancholy.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: If thou do'st envie mee
There is some reason for't, thou do'st imagine
I have had pleasure in my dayes, but never,
Never, so sweete a skirmish, how like joy
Shee grew to my embraces, not a kisse
But had Elisium in't.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: I was a rascall.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: If thou didst know but halfe so much as I
Or couldst imagine it, thou wouldst acknowledge
Thy selfe worse then a rascall on Record.
I have not words to expresse, how soft, how bountious
How everie thing a man with full desires
Could wish a Lady, do not question mee
Further; tis too much happines to remember
I am sorry I have said so much.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Was not I curst
To loose my monie, and such delicate sport?

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: But that I love thee well shud'st nere injoy her.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Why?

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: I would almost cut thy throate.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: You wod not.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.P: But take her, and if thou part'st with her, one night more for lesse then both the Indies thou't loose by her, shee has paid me for my service, I aske nothing else.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: If she be such aprecious armefull Will
I thinke you may be satisfied.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Take heede,
And understand thy selfe a little better:
I thinke you may be satisfied with what?
A handsome wench 'tis heresie recant it
I never shall be satisfied.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: You do not purpose.
Purpose a new incounter.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: For thy sake
Tis possible I may not, I would have
My game kept for me; what I have done
Was upon your entreatie, if you have
The like occasion hereafter I
Should have a hard heart to deny thee Jacke.

SP.SPEAKER: VVi.
SP.L: Thou hast fir'd my blood, that I could call backe time,
And be possest of what my indiscretion
Gave up to thy enjoying, but I am comforted,
She thinks 'twas I, and we hereafter may
Be free in our delights: now, sir, the newes
With you? Enter Page.

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.L: My mistresse did command my diligence
To find you out and pray you come to speake with her.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: When I am at leasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.L: Tis of consequence,
Shee sayes, and much concernes you.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Is Penelope▪
With her?

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.L: Not when she sent mee forth.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Let her expect: waite you on me.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: I spie my blustering Gamester.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: The yonger ferret.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: I care not if I allow thee a fit of mirth
But your boy must be in comfort.

SP.SPEAKER: Dwi.
SP.L: Pray, sir, do not behave your selfe so furiouslie,
Your breath is able to blow downe a house, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Ne.
SP.L: My Uncle shall build 'em up againe, oh Dwindle,
Thou dost not know what honor 'tis to bee
So boisterous, I would take the wall now
Of my Lord Maiors Gyants.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Doe as I bid you, sirra.

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.L: Alas, sir, hee'le devoure me.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: He shanot hurt thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.L: Be at my backe then pray, sir, now I thinke on't
I have the beard here too with which I frighted
Our maides last night.

SP.SPEAKER: Dwi.
SP.L: You know these gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Ne.
SP.L: Hazard, and Wilding? how i'st? how i'st Bulchins?
Wo'dye had beene with us; I ha so mald a Captaine
O'th traine band yonder.

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.L: Is not your name Barnacle?

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Ancient Pearre?

SP.SPEAKER: Ne.
SP.L: What's this?

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: The admiration of the Towne.

SP.SPEAKER: Ne.
SP.L: For what?

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: For valour.

SP.SPEAKER: Ne.
SP.L: This inch and a halfe?

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Ther's the wonder, oh the spirit, the tall spirit
Within him he has the soule of a Giant.

SP.SPEAKER: Ne.
SP.L: He has but a dwarfs body, ancient Ptarre.

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.L: Sirra, how dare you name a Captaine?
Thou tunne of ignorance, he shall eate my Pistol,
And save me the discharge.

SP.SPEAKER: Ne.
SP.L: Tell me of a tun? i'le drinke twenty tunnes to thy
Health, who shall hinder me if I have a
Minde too't, your Pistol's a Pepper-corne, I will eate
Up an armory, if my stomacke serve, so long as I
Have mony to pay for't, and you were as little agen
As you are: fright me with your potguns, my name's
Barnacle, sir, call me what you please, and my
Mans name's Dwindle, and you goe there to, do not
Thinke but I have seene fire-Dakes afore now though
I never talk'd on't, and Rackets too, though my man
Be a Coxcombe here, and balls of wild-fire, no dispraise
To you; d'ee thinke to thunder me with your Picke
Tooth by your side?

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.L: Let my sword shew him but one flash of lightning
To singe the haire of his head off.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Good ancient Petarre.

SP.SPEAKER: Dwi.
SP.L: Tis a very divell in decimo sexto, Peter d'e call him?

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.L: Thou dogbolt and cozen germane to Cerbenus.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Two heads once remov'd, hee's somewhat like him.

SP.SPEAKER: Ne.
SP.L: I begin to thinke.

SP.SPEAKER: Dwi.
SP.L: And I begin to—

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.L: Agen.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: He does but thinke.

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.L: He thinke? is this a place for him to thinke in?
Minotaure, vanish immediately, or I will shoot death
From my Mustachios and kill thee like a Porcupine.

SP.SPEAKER: Ne.
SP.L: Ancient Petarre, I know thy name and I
Honor it, thar't one of the most vaineglorious
Peeces of fire-worke that ever water wet. I am a
Gentleman, and if I have say'd any thing to disgust
Thee, I can aske thee forgivenes, as well as the
Proudest vassell on 'em all, extend thy paw, thou
Invincible Epitome of Hercules, and let thy servant
Kisse it.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Come pray, sir, be reconcil'd; he submits.

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.P: I see thou hast something in thee of a Soldier, to no Pur∣pose, and I will cherish it. Thou art a raskall in thy under∣standing, thou shat excuse me, Turke, in honorable love: I re∣member thy great grand-Father was hang'd for robbing a Ped∣ler-woman of sixe yards of inckle, and thou mayst, (mauger the Herald) in a right line, challenge the gallowes by his copie; mongrell of mongrell Hall. I am thy humble servant, and will cut the throate of any man that sayes thou hast ey∣ther wit or honesty more then is fit for a gentleman. Command my sword, my lungs, my life, thou art a puffe, a mulligrube, a Metaphysicall Coxcombe, and I honour you with all my hart.

SP.SPEAKER: Ne.
SP.L: I thanke you noble ancient, and kinde gentlemen.
Come Dwindle, wee'le go rore somewhere else.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Was ever such an offe? Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: The boy id hit his humour excellently.
Here, cherish thy wit.

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.L: Now shall I tell my mistresse you'le come to her?

SP.SPEAKER: VVi.
SP.L: How officious you are for your mistresse, sirra?
What said shee I came not home all night?

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.L: Nothing to me; but my eyes ne're beheld
Her looke more pleasantly.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Now farewell Jacke, I neede not urge your secresie
Touching your mistres, I have mounted for you:
Only i'le caution you, looke when you meete
That you performe your busines handsomely.
I ha begun so well shee may suspect else,
And put thee out of service, if shee doe,
You know your wages▪ I shall laugh at thee,
And hartilie; so farewell, farewell Jacke. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: VVi.
SP.L: To say the truth I have shewed my selfe a coxcombe.
A pox a play that made me double looser.
For ought I know, she may admit me never
To such a turne agen, and then I ha punished
My selfe ingeniouslie.
SP.STAGE: Enter Mistris Wilding, Penelope, and Mistris Leonora, a Servant waiting upon them.
SP.L: My wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Pag.
SP.L: My Mistresse, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Keepe you at distance, Penelope, and Leonora,
Shee's as the boy reported something more
Pleasant then ordinarie.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.L: Tis hee good cozen,
Pretend some busines▪ offer at some wares,
Or aske the Gold-smith what your Diamond's worth,
Something to trifle time away, while I
Speake with my husband a few words.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Shee comes toward me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.L: I can containe no longer,
How d'ee sweete-hart?

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Well, but a little melancholy.
You looke more sprightfully wife, something has pleas'd you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.L: It has indeede, and if it be no staine
To modestie, I would enquire how you
Sped the last night.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: I lost my money.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.L: I doe not meane that game.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: I am not betrai'd I hope; do not meane that game?

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.L: Y'are a fine gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Tis so, could she not keepe her owne counsell?

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.L: And have behav'd your selfe most wittilie,
And I may say most wrongfully: this will
Bee much for your honor, when 'tis knowne.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: What will be knowne?

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.L: Do you not blush? oh fie.
Is there no modestie in man?

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: What riddle
Have you got now? I wonot yet seeme conscious.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.L: Tis time then to be plaine, it was a wonder
I could be so long silent, did you like
Your last nights lodging?

SP.SPEAKER: Wil.
SP.L: Very, very well;
I went not to bed all night.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.L: You did not lie with
Mistresse Penelope my kinswoman?

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Refuse me if I did.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.L: You neede not sweare;
But 'twas no fault of yours, no fault no vertue:
But 'tis no place to expostulate these actions.
In breife know 'twas my plott, for I observ'd
Which way your warme affection mov'd, & wrought
So with my honest cozen to supplie
Her wanton place, that with some shame at last,
I might deceive your hard heart into kindnes.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: That, that agen sweete wife, and be a little
Serious; was it your plott to excuse your cozen,
And be the bed-fellow?

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.L: Heaven knowes 'tis truth.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: I am fitted, fitted with a paire of hornes
Of my owne making.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.L: Thanke, and thinke upon
That providence that would not have you lost
In such a Forrest of loose thoughts, and bee
Your selfe agen; I am your hand-maid still,
And have learned so much pietie to conceale
What ever should dishonor you.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: It budds,
It budds alreadie. I shall turne starke mad,
Horne mad.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.L: What aile you? are you vext because
Your wantonnesse thriv'd so well?

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Well with a vengance.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.L: I did expect your thanks.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Yes, I do thanke you, thanke you heartilie,
Most infinitly thanke you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.L: Doth this merit
No other payment but your scorne, then know
Bad man, 'tis in my power to be reveng'd,
And what I had a resolution
Should sleepe in silent darknes, now shall looke
Day in the face, i'le publish to the World
How I am wrong'd, and with what stubbornesse
You have despis'd the cure of your owne fame;
Nor shall my Cozen suffer in her honor▪
I stoope as low as earth to shew my dutie,
But too much trampl'd on I rise to tell
The World I am a woman.

SP.SPEAKER: VVi.
SP.L: No, no; harke you,
I doe not mocke you, I am taken with
The conceit, what a fine thing I have made my selfe.
Nere speake on't, thy device shall take; i'le love thee.
And kisse thee for't, tha'st paid me handsomelie:
An admirable plot, and follow'd cunninglie,
I'le see thee anon agen, and lie with thee
To night, without a stratagemme. The gentlewomen
Expect thee; keepe all close, deare wife, no sentences.
I am trick'd and trim'd at my owne charges rarely,
I'le seeke out some body agen. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.L: I have presum'd too much upon your patience,
I have discover'd, and I hope t'will take.

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.L: I wish it may.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.L: You are sad still, Leonora.
Remove these thoughts: come i'le waite on you now
To the Exchange: some toyes may there strike off
Their sad remembrance.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: I attend you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.L: Farewell.

SP.SPEAKER: Ke.
SP.L: The gentleman that was yesterday to speake with you
Is come againe to visite you.

SP.SPEAKER: Beo.
SP.L: S. Richard Hurry?

SP.SPEAKER: Ke.
SP.L: The same, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: You may admit him.

SP.SPEAKER: Ke.
SP.L: Men of his quality
Do seldome court affliction, this, I must
Allow, is a most noble gratitude
For those good offices my father did him.

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.L: Sir, the respects I owe you make me againe
Solliciter for your saftie, and although
On the first proposition it appeare
Strange to you, and perhapps incredible,
Which might dispose you to the slow embrace
Of what I tendred, yet againe brought to you
After a time to examine and consider
What most concernes you, I am confident,
You will accept, and thanke me▪

SP.SPEAKER: Beo.
SP.L: Noble sir.
You doe expresse so are is bountie, men
Will sloely imitate; I am not soe
Lost in my wilde misfortune, but my reason
Will guide me to acknowledge and paie backe
My service and my selfe, for so much charity
As you have pleas'd to shew me.

SP.SPEAKER: Vio.
SP.L: Here's for thy paines: they are the same; make good
Thy word, and place me where I may unseene
Heare their discourse.

SP.SPEAKER: Ke.
SP.L: This way.

SP.SPEAKER: Beo.
SP.L: But with your pardon,
I would desire to heare agen how much
I shall be oblig'd that knowing the extent
Of your desert I maie pay backe a duty,
That may in every circumstance become
My fortune and the benefit.

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.L: Then thus: you are a Prisoner; that alone
Is misery,
But yours the greater, in that guilt of blood,
Not summes that may bee recompenc'd, detaine you.
I'le not dispute the circumstance, Delamore
Slaine by your hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Beo.
SP.L: I have confest,
The first jurie having found it murder.

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.L: His blood calls to the law for justice, and you cannot
Left to your selfe, and looking on the fact,
Expect with any comfort what must follow.
Yet I in pity of your suffrings,
In pity of your youth which would bee else
Untimely blasted, offer to remove
Your sorrowes, make you free and right againe,
With cleere satisfaction to the Law.

SP.SPEAKER: Beo.
SP.L: Good sir,
Pray give me leave to doubt here. I see not
How ere your will and charitie may bee active
In my desiresse to save me, that you can
Assure my life and freedome, since in causes
Of such high nature, lawes must have their course,
Whose streame as it were wickednesse to pollute,
It were vanitie for any private man
To thinke he could resist. I speake not this
To have you imagine I despise my life,
But to expresse my feares your will does flatter you
Bove what your power can reach.

SP.SPEAKER: Pa.
SP.L: For that I urge not
My beeing a Commissioner alone
To doe you service, I have friends in Court,
And great ones, when the rigor of the Law
Hath sentenc'd you to mediate your pardon:
Nor takes it from the justice of a Prince,
Where provocation and not malice makes
Guilty, to save, whom the sharpe letter doomes
Sometimes to execution: I am to farre
From doubting your discharge, that I dare forfeit
My life if I secure not yours from any
Danger for this offence.

SP.SPEAKER: Beo.
SP.L: You speake all comfort
Which way can I deserve this?

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: That i'le shew you.
I had an obligation to your father
Whose love when all my fortunes were i'th ebbe,
And desperatelie, releev'd mee with large summes;
By whose carefull manage I arryu'd at what
I am, and I should be a rebell to
Nature and goodnesse not to love the sonne
Of such a friend by his misfortune made
Ripe for my gratitude.

SP.SPEAKER: Beo
SP.L: You speake your bountie,
But teach not all this while how to deserve it.

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.L: Tis done by your acceptance of my daughter
To bee your Bride.

SP.SPEAKER: Be.
SP.L: To be my Bride? pray tell tell me
Is she deform'd or wanton, what vice has shee?

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Vice, sir, she will deserve as good a husband,
Shee is handsome though I say't, and shall be rich too.

SP.SPEAKER: Beo.
SP.L: Shee is too good, if she be faire or vertuous.
Pardon, I know she is both: but you amaze me,
I did expect conditions of danger:
A good wife is a blessing above health;
You teach mee to deserve my life first from you
By offering a happinesse beyond it.

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.L: If you finde love to accept, 'tis the reward
I looke for, Leonora shall obey
Or quit a father.

SP.SPEAKER: Be.
SP.L: Ha goodnesse defend.
I know you doe but mocke me, and upbraid
My act, that kild her servant: wound mee still,
I have deserv'd her curse: I see her weepe,
And every teare accuse me.

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.L: May I never
Thrive in my Prayers to Heaven, if what I offer
I wish not heartilie confirm'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Bu.
SP.L: I now
Suspect you are not Leonora father,
'Twere better you dissembled, then made her
So past all hope of beeing cur'd agen:
I marry Leonora! can her soule
Thinke on so foule a rape, she cannot sure.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Shee shall; I command.

SP.SPEAKER: Be.
SP.L: By vertue, but
Shee shanot, nor would I to graspe an Empire
Tempt her to so much staine, let her tell downe
Her Virgin teares, on Delamores cold Marble,
Sigh to his dust, and call revenge upon
His head whose anger sent him to those shades,
From whence she nere must see him; this will justifie
Shee lov'd the dead: it were impietie
One smile should blesse her murderer, and how ere
You are pleas'd to complement with my affliction,
I know she cannot finde one thought without her
So foule to looke upon me.

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.P: Let it rest on that, will you confern and timely make provision for your saftie?

SP.SPEAKER: Beo.
SP.L: For my life
You meane, now on the chance, then I may live
You are confident, and thinke it not impossible
Your daughter may affect me▪ ther's at once
Two blessings, are they not and mightie ones,
Considering what I am, how low, how lost
T'oth common aire?

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.L: Now you are wise.

SP.SPEAKER: Beo.
SP.L: But if
Your daughter would confirme this, and propound
Her selfe my victorie.

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.L: What then?

SP.SPEAKER: Beo.
SP.L: I should condemne her, and despise the conquest▪
These things may bribe an Atheist not a Lover.
But you perhaps are ignorant, I have given
My faith away irrevocablie, 'tis
The wealth of Violante, and I wonot
Basely steale backe a thought, and yet I thanke you,
I am not so inhumane.

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.L: Will you not
Preferre your life
To honor and religion?

SP.SPEAKER: Beo.
SP.L: For shame be silent could you make me Lord
Of my owne destiny, and that Leonora
Had empires for her dower, and courted mee
With all the flatteries of life, to quit
My vowes to Violante, I would die
Upon her bosome to meete death▪

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.L: And death
You must expect which will take off this braverie.

SP.SPEAKER: Beo.
SP.L: And I will kisse it, kisse it, like a Bride.

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.L: So resolute?

SP.SPEAKER: Beo.
SP.L: And if I cannot live
My Violantes, I will die her sacrifice.
Good sir, no more, you do not well to trouble
The quiet of a Prisoner thus that cannot
Be a too carefull Steward of those minuts
Left him to make his peace, tempt me no further:
The Earth is not so fixt as my resolues,
Rather to die then in one thought transplant
My love from Violante.

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.L: Bee undone,
And this contempt shall hasten the divorce
Of soule and love, die and be soone forgotten. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Beo.
SP.L: My Violante, if there can be any joy
Neighbour too so much greife, i'le powre it out
To pay thy bounteous visit, if my eyes
Admit no fellowship in weeping, 'tis
Because my heart which saw thee first, would bid
Thee welcome thither, scorning; to acknowledge
There can be any thing but joy where thou art.

SP.SPEAKER: Vio.
SP.L: But sadnes my deere Beaumont, while there is
A cause that maks thee Prisoner, I must weepe
And empty many springs, my eyes are now
No prophets of thy sorrow but the witnes,
And when I thinke of death that waits upon thee
I wither to a Ghost.

SP.SPEAKER: Beo.
SP.L: Why Violante,
We must all die, restraine these weeping Fountaines,
Keepe'em till I am dead, dispence 'em then
Upon my grave, and I shall grow agen,
And in the sweete disguise of a faire Garden
Salute the spring that gave mee greene and odour.
Why should not love transforme us?

SP.SPEAKER: Vio.
SP.L: Bee not lost
In these imaginations.

SP.SPEAKER: Beo.
SP.L: Or perhapps
Th▪ast ambition, she whose love made up
A wonder to the World beside the pledge
Of duty to her Lord, fam'd Arthemisia
Shall bee no more in storie for her Tombe:
For on the Earth that weighes my body downe
When I am dead, thy teares by the cold breath
Of Heaven congeal'd to Beaumonts memorie,
Shall raise a monument of Pearle to our doe
The great Mausolus Sepulcher.

SP.SPEAKER: Vio.
SP.L: No more
Of this vaine language, if you have any pittie
On the poore Violante.

SP.SPEAKER: Ber.
SP.L: I ha done,
And yet I am going now to a long silence;
Allow my sorrow to take leave Violante

SP.SPEAKER: Vio.
SP.L: It shall be so, be valiant my heart
Beaumont I come not to take leave of thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Be.
SP.L: Perhapps you'le see me agen.

SP.SPEAKER: Vio.
SP.L: Agen and often,
Thy starres are gentle to thee, many daies,
And yeeres are yet betweene thee and that time
That threatens losse of breath; see, I can thus
Disperse the Clouds sate heavie on my brow,
Wipe the moisture hence, tis day agen;
Take beames into thy eye, and let them sinke
Upon thy better fortune, live, live happilie.

SP.SPEAKER: Be.
SP.L: Is Delamore alive?

SP.SPEAKER: Vio.
SP.L: Dead and interr'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Be.
SP.L: From what can this hope rise?

SP.SPEAKER: Vio.
SP.L: From thy selfe Beaumont;
If thou wilt save thy selfe, I have heard all,
And by the duty of my love am bound
To hide your resolution, can you be
So merciles to your selfe to refuse life
When it is offer'd with the best advantage
Is Leonoras love? a price that should
Buy you from all the World? be counsell'd sir,
Oh, do not loose your selfe in a vaine passion
For thought of me, I cancell all your vowes,
And give you backe your heart, bee free againe
If you will promise me to live and love.

SP.SPEAKER: Be.
SP.L: Leonora.

SP.SPEAKER: Vio.
SP.L: That best of woman-kinde, a mine of sweetnes.

SP.SPEAKER: Be.
SP.L: But can you leave mee then?

SP.SPEAKER: Vio.
SP.L: I justifie
Thy choice of me in that, that to preserve thee
Dare give thee backe agen, be Leonoras,
For being mine th'art lost to all the World
Better a thousand times, thou be made hers
Then we both loose, i'le pawne my faith sheele love thee
I'le be content to heare my Beaumonts well,
And visite thee sometimes like a glad sister,
And never beg a kisse, but if I weepe
At any time when we are together,
Do not beleeve 'tis sorrow makes my eyes
So wet, but joy to see my Beaumont living:
As it is now to hope.

SP.SPEAKER: Be.
SP.L: If thou dost meane thus
Thou dost the more to inflame me to be constant,
Be not a miracle and I may be tempted
To love my life above thee, by this kisse,
Oh, give me but another in my death
It will restore me by this innocent hand,
While as I wish my soule I wonot leave thee
For the Worlds Kingdome.

SP.SPEAKER: Vio.
SP.L: But you must, unlesse
You change for Leonora, thinke of that,
Thinke ere you be to rash.

SP.SPEAKER: Be.
SP.L: I'le thinke of thee,
And honor to be read, I love Violante
But never could deserve her, live thou happie,
And by thy vertue teach a neerer way
To heaven, we may meete yonder, do not make me
More miserable then I am, by adding perjurie
To my bloody sinne, the memory of thee
Will at my execution advance
My spirit to a —that men shall thinke
I have chang'd my cause for martyrdome.

SP.SPEAKER: Vio.
SP.L: Then here
As of a dying man I take my leave,
Farewell unhappie Beaumont, i'le pray for thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Beo.
SP.L: Tis possible I may live yet and be thine.

SP.SPEAKER: Vio.
SP.L: These teares embalme thee
If in this World we never meete
My life is buried in thy winding sheete.

SP.SPEAKER: Beo.
SP.L: This exceeds all my sorrow.

DIV2.HEAD: Act. V.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: I am justly punish'd now for all my tricks,
And pride o'th flesh, I had ambition
To make men cuckolds, now the divell has paid me,
Paid me i'th same coine, and i'le compare
My forehead with the broadest of my neighbors:
But ere it spreads too monstrous, I must have
Some plot upon this Hazard, he supposes
He has enjoy'd Penelope, and my tricke
To drive the opinion home, to get him marrie her
And make her satisfaction: the wench
Has oft commended him, he may be wonne too't,
I never meant to part with all her portion,
Perhaps heele thanke me for the moytie.
And this dispos'd on shee's conjur'd to silence.
It must bee so.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Jacke Wilding how ist man?
How goes the Plough at home? what sayes the Lady
Guinever that was humbled in your absence?
You have the credit with her, all the glorie
Of my nights worke; does shee not hide her eyes,
And blush, and cry you are a fine gentleman.
Turne a toside, or drop a handkercher,
And stoope, and take occasion to leere,
And laugh upon thee?

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Nothing lesse, I know not
What tha'st done to her, but shees very sad.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha
SP.L: Sad; i'le be hang'd then.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Thou must imagine
I did the best to comfort her▪

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Shee's melancholy
For my absence man, i'le keepe her company
Agen to night.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Shee thinks 'twas I enjoy'd her.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Let her thinke whom she will, so we may couple.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: And nothing now but sighes, and cries I have
Undone her.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Shee's a foole, I hurt her not,
Shee cried not out I am sure, and for my body
I defie the Colledge of Physitions:
Let a jurie of Virgins search me.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: To be plaine,
Although shee has no thought but I was her bed-fellow,
You are the only argument of her sadnes.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: How can that be?

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: When I had merrilie
Excus'd what had beene done, she fetch'd a sight,
And with some teares reveal'd her love to you,
That she had lov'd you long, but by this act
Of mine, d'ee marke, she was become unworthie
To hope for so good fortune, I cannot tell,
But she is strangelie passionate.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: For me?

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: For you, but tho art soft and tender-hearted,
And in that confidence I did forbeare
To tell her who had done the deede.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: You did so:
'Twas wiselie done▪ now I collect my selfe,
Shee has sometime smil'd upon mee.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Nay beleeve it
Shee is taken with thee above all the World.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: And yet shee was content you should
'Bove all the World.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: But 'twas your better fate
To be the man, it was her destiny
To have the right performance, thou art a gentleman▪
And canst not but consider the poore gentlewoman.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: What wod'st ha me doe?

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Make her amends, and marrie her.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Marrie a strumpet?

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: You had first possession,
And thao'st beene married earlier could'st but had
Her maiden-head, besides no bodie knowes but we our selves.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Bee not abus'd I had
No maiden head.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: My greater torment: come, come thou art modest;
Heaven knowes she may be desperate.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: A faire riddance,
Wee have enough o'th tribe, I am sorrie I cannot
Furnish her expedition with a paire
Of my owne Garters.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: I— of Athens growne,
I know thou art more charitable, shee may prove
A happie wife, what woman but has frailty?

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Let her make the best on't, set up shop
I'th Strand, or Westminster, she may have custome,
And come to speake most learnedlie i'th Nose
Bid her keepe quarter with the Constable.
And Justices Clarke and shee in time may purchace.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Shee has a portion will maintaine her like
A gentlewoman and your wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Where ist?

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: In my possession, and I had rather thou
Shouldst have it then another.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Thanke you heartily,
A single life has single care, pray keepe it.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Come thou shalt know I love thee, thou shalt have
More by a thousand pound, then I resolv'd
To part with cause I wod call thee cozen too;
A brace of thousands Will, shee has to her Portion,
I hop'd to put her off with halfe the summe;
That's truth some yonger brother wod ha thank'd mee,
And given my quietus tush, 'tis frequent
With men that are so trusted, i'st a match,

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Two thousand pound will make a maiden-head
That's crooked straight agen.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Th'art in the right,
Or for the better sound, as the Grammarians
Say, I will call it twentie hundred pound
Belady a pretty stocke, enough and neede be,
To buy up halfe the maiden-heads in a Countie.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Heer's my hand i'le consider on't no further,
Is shee prepar'd?

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Leave that to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: No more.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: I'le instantly about it. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Ha, ha.
The project moves better then I expected,
What paines he takes out of his ignorance?

SP.SPEAKER: Ba.
SP.L: Oh! Sir I am glad I ha fonud you.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: I was not lost.

SP.SPEAKER: Ba.
SP.L: My Nephew, sir, my Nephew.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: What of him.

SP.SPEAKER: Vn.
SP.L: He's undone, he's undone, you have undone him.

SP.SPEAKER: Ba.
SP.L: What's the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Vn.
SP.L: You have made him, sir, so valiant I am afraid
He's not long liv'd, he quarrells now with every body
And rores and dominers and shak's the pen-houses.
A woman that sold pudding-pies, but tooke
The wall on him, and he trips up her heeles,
And downe fell all, the kennell ranne pure white-pot
What shall I doe I feare he will be kild:
I take a little priviledge my selfe
Because I threaten to disinherite him,
But no body else dares talke or meddle with him
Is there no way to take him downe agen
And make him coward?

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: There are wayes to tame him.

SP.SPEAKER: Ba.
SP.L: Now I wish heartilie you had beaten him
For the hundred pound.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: That may bee done yet

SP.SPEAKER: Ba.
SP.L: I'st not to late? but do you thinke 'twill humble him?
I expect every minute hee's abroad
To heare he has kild some body, or receive him
Brought home with halfe his braines or but one legg.
Good sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: What wod you have me doe?

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: I'le pay you for't
If you will beate him soundlie, sir, and leave him
But as you found him; for if hee continue
A blade and be not kild, he wonot scape
The gallowes long, and 'tis not for my honor
He should be hang'd

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: I shall deserve as much,
To allay this mettall, as I did to quicken it.

SP.SPEAKER: Ba.
SP.L: Nay 'tis my meaning to content you, sir.
And I shall take it as a favour too,
If for the same price you made him valiant,
You will unblade him: here's the money sir,
As waightie gold as tother; cause you should not
Lay it on lightlie; breake no limb, and bruise him
Three-quarters dead, I care not; he may live
Many a faire day after it.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: You shew
An Uncles love in this, trust me to cure
His valour.

SP.SPEAKER: Ba.
SP.L: Hee is here; do but observe.
And beate him, sir, accordinglie.

SP.SPEAKER: Ne.
SP.L: How now Uncle?

SP.SPEAKER: Ba.
SP.L: Thou art no Nephew of mine, tha'rta rascall
I'le be at no more charge to make thee a gentleman,
Paie for your Dice and drinkings, I shall have
The Surgeons bills brought shortly home to me,
Be troubled to baile thee from the Sessions,
And afterwards make friends to the Recorder
For a Repreeve, yes, I will see thee hang'd first.

SP.SPEAKER: Ne.
SP.L: And be at the charge to paint the gallowes too;
If I have a minde the waites shall play before me,
And i'le be hang'd in state three stories high, Uncle:
But first i'le cut your throate.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Blesse me, defend me.

SP.SPEAKER: Acr
SP.L: How now, what▪s the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Sel
SP.L: Master Barnacle?

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Ther's an ungratious bird of mine owne nest,
Will murder me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lit.
SP.L: He wonot sure?

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Put up,
And aske your Uncle presentlie forgivenesse;
Or I will hoffe thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Ne.
SP.L: Hoffe me? I will put up
At thy entreatie.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Gentlemen you remember
This noble gallant.

SP.SPEAKER: Acr.
SP.L: Cozen of yours I take it.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Cozen to a killing, in your company
Lent me a box o'th eare.

SP.SPEAKER: Ne.
SP.L: No, no, I gave it,
I gave it freelie; keepe it, never thinke on't,
I can make bold with thee another time,
Wo'd't'had beene twentie.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: One's too much to keepe.
I am a Gamester, and remembred alwayes
To pay the box; ther's first your principall,
Take that for the use.

SP.SPEAKER: Ne.
SP.L: Use? wod thad'st given my Uncle.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: They have cost him already two hundred pounds
And upwards, shotten Herring, thing of noise.

SP.SPEAKER: Ne.
SP.L: Oh, for my man Dwindle
And his basket-hilt now my Uncle shall rue this.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Downe presentlie, and before these gentlemen
Desire his pardon.

SP.SPEAKER: Ne.
SP.L: How, desire his pardon?

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Then let this go round.

SP.SPEAKER: Ne.
SP.L: I will aske his pardon, I beseech you Uncle.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: And sweare.

SP.SPEAKER: Ne.
SP.L: And do sweare.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: To be obedient, never more to quarrell.

SP.SPEAKER: Ne.
SP.L: Why looke you gentlemen, I hope you are persuaded
By being kicke so patiently, that I am
Not over valiant.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: I suspect him still.

SP.SPEAKER: Ne.
SP.L: For more assurance doe you kicke me too.
Am not I patient and obedient now?
Will you have any more gentlemen, before I rise?

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: If ever he prove rebellious in act,
Or language, let me know it.

SP.SPEAKER: Ne.
SP.L: Will you not give
Me leave to roare abroad a little for
My credit?

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Never, sirra, now i'le tame you.
I thanke you gentlemen, command me for
This curtesie.

SP.SPEAKER: Ne.
SP.L: Tis possible I may
With lesse noise grow more valiant hereafter:
Till then I am in all your debts.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar
SP.L: Be ruld,
And be my Nephew againe: this was my love,
My love deere Nephew.

SP.SPEAKER: Ne.
SP.L: If your love consist
In kicking Uncle, let me love you agen,

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Follow me, sirra.

SP.SPEAKER: Acr.
SP.L: Then his Uncle paid for't?

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Hartilie, hartilie.

SP.SPEAKER: Lit.
SP.L: I thought there was some tricke.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: And whether are you going gentlemen?

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.L: We are going to visit Beomont in the Prison.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Tis charity, but that I have deepe engagements,
I'de waite upon you, but commend my service to him,
I'le visit him ere night; you saw not Wilding?

SP.SPEAKER: A.L.S.
SP.L: We saw his wife and kins-woman enter
Sr. Richard Hurries halfe an houre ago.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha▪
SP.L: His kins-woman? I thanke you.
You have sav'd me travaile, farewell gentlemen,
Farewell.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Leonora, and Violante, Mistris Wilding; and Penelope.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: My father has some designe, and bad me send for thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Y'are both too sad, come, come, we must divert
This melancholy.

SP.SPEAKER: Vio.
SP.L: I beseech your pardon,
But is my Beomont sent for?

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: Yes: we are
Too private.

SP.SPEAKER: Vio.
SP.L: I much feare Leonora now,
Shee lookes not sad enough, although I could▪
Resign my interest freely to preserve him,
I would not willingly be present when
They enterchange hearts, slie will shew too much
A tyrant, if she be not satisfied
With what was mine, but I must be moite
To be their triumph.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.L: Master Hazard?

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: All things
Succeed beyond your thought, pray give me a little
Opportunitie with your kins-woman. Exit. Mi. Leo. Vio.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: Weele withdraw.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: I know not how to wooe her now, sweet Lady?

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.L: Your pleasure, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Pray let me aske you a question.
If you had lost your way and met one,
A traviler like my selfe, that knew the coast
O'th countrey, would you thanke him to direct you?

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.L: That common manners would instruct.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: I thinke so.

SP.SPEAKER: Pene,
SP.L: But there are many waies to the wood, and which
Would you desire, the nearest path, and safest
Or that which leads about?
Without all question.
The neerest and the safest.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Can you love then?

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.L: I were a divell else:

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: And can you love a man?

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.L: A man, what else, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Y'are so farre on your way. Now love but me,
Y'are at your journies end, what say to me?

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.L: Nothing, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: That's no answer, you must say something.

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.L: I hope you'le not compell me.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: D'ee heare Lady?
Setting this foolerie aside: I know
You cannot chuse but love me.

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.L: Why?

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: I have beene told so.

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.L: You are easie of beleefe
I thinke I should be best acquainted with
My owne thoughts, and I dare not be so desperate
To conclude.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Come you lie; I could have given't
In smother phrase: y'are a dessembling gentlewoman.
I know your heart, you have lov'd me a great while.
What should I play the foole? if you remember
I urg'd some wild discourse in the behalfe
Of your lewd kindsman, 'twas a triall of thee
That humor made me love thee; and since that thy vertue.

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.L: Indeede sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Indeede, sir? why I have beene contracted to thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.L: How long?

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: This halfe houre, know thy portion, and shall have it.

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.L: Strange.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Nay i'le have thee too.

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.L: You will?

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: I cannot helpe it; thy kind cozen will have it so:
Tis his owne plott, to make thee amends, ist not
Good mirth? but 'tis not love to thee or mee,
But to have me possest hee is no cuckold:
I see through his device, thou art much beholding to him:
He meant to have put thee off with halfe thy portion,
But that if things come out we should keepe counsell.
Say ist a match? I have two thousand pound too
I thanke the Dice, lett's put our stocks together,
Children will follow; he is here already.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: So close! I am glad on't, this prepares, Will Hazard,
And my yong Cozen; a word Penelope.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Now will he make all sure.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: You us'd me courselie,
But I have forgot it, what discourse have you
With this gentleman?

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.L: He would seeme to be a Sutor.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Entertaine him; d'ee heare, you may do worse, be rul'd.
'Twas in my thought to move it, does he not
Talke strangelie?

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.L: Of what?

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Of nothing, let me counsell you
To love him, call him husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.L: I resolve
Never to marry without your consent.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Gentlemen, welcome.

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.L: If you bestow me, sir, I wil be confident
I am not lost, I must confesse I love him.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: No more: then loose no time, kinde gentlemen,
Y'are come most seasonably to be the witnesses
Of my consent, I have examin'd both
Your hearts, and freely give thee here my kinswoman:
No sooner shall the Church pronounce your married
But challenge what is hers.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Two thousand pound.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: I do confesse it is her portion
You shanot stay to talke, nay gentlemen,
Pray see the busines finish'd.

SP.SPEAKER: A.L.S.
SP.L: We attend you.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: So, so, this will confirme him in the opinion,
Penelope was the creature he injoy'd,
And keepe off all suspition of my wife,
Who is still honest in the imagination
That only I embrac'd her, all secure,
And my browes smooth agen, who can deride me?
But I my selfe, ha, that's too much I know it,
And spight of these tricks am a Cornelius.
Cannot I bribe my conscience to be ignorant?
Why then I ha done nothing, yes advanc'd
The man, that grafted shame upon my fore-head:
Vexation, parted with two thousand pound,
And am no lesse a cuckold then before
Was I predestin'd to this shame and mockerie?
Where were my braines? yet why am I impatient?
Unlesse betrai'd he cannot reach the knowledge,
And then no matter—yes I am curst agen,
My torment multiplies, how can he thinke
He plaid the wanton with Penelope
When he finds her a maide? that ruines all:
I wod she had beene strumpeted, he knowes
My wives Virginitie to well, I am lost,
And must be desperate, kill him; no, my wife.
Not so good, death is over blacke and horrid,
And I am growne ridiculous to my selfe.
I must do some thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.L: Master Wilding, welcome,
Y'ave beene a great a stranger.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Do you know me?

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.L: Know you?

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: They say I am much alter'd alate.

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.L: There is some alteration in your forehead.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: My forehead?

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.L: Tis not smooth enough, you're troubled:
Your wife's within.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Shee loves your daughter, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.L: When saw you Master Beaumont?

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Not to day.

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.L: I have sent for him; pray stay, and witnes
His further examination, I propounded
A way to doe him good but he is obstinate.
Would I could change condition with him!

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: He is not troubled now with being a cuckold,
You shall command.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Mistris Wilding, and a Servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.L: Your husband Lady,

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Wife you are a whore
You shall know more hereafter,
I must goe live i'th Forrest.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.L: And I i'th Common.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Sheele turne prostitute.

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.L: Attend him hither. Master Beaumont's come
Nay you shall favour me so much, here's the gentleman
Already.

SP.SPEAKER: Bea.
SP.L: Sir, your pleasure? by your command I am brought hither,
I hope you have no more to charge me with
Then freelie I have confest.

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.L: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Bea.
SP.L: I must answer
You can have but my life to satisfie;
Pray speake my accusation.

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.L: Besides the offence knowne and examin'd
You are guilty
Of that which all good natures do abhorre.

SP.SPEAKER: Bea.
SP.L: You have a priviledge, but do not make me
Good sir, to appeare monstrous, who are my
Accusers?

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.L: I am one.

SP.SPEAKER: Bea.
SP.L: And my judge too:
I have small hope to plead then, but proceede,
And name my trespasse.

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.L: That which includes all
That man should hate; ingratitude.

SP.SPEAKER: Bea
SP.L: You have
Preferrd a large inditement, and are the first
That ever chargd me with't, it is a staine
My soule held most at distance, but descend
To some particular; this offence doth rise
Or fall in the degree, or reference
To persons sinn'd against, to whom have I
Beene so ingratefull?

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.L: Ingrate as high as murder.

SP.SPEAKER: Bea.
SP.L: To whom?

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.L: Thy selfe, to whom that life thou oughtest to cherish
Thou hast undone

SP.SPEAKER: Bea.
SP.L: I am not so uncharitable
How ere you please to urge it, but I know
Why you conclude so, let me, sir, be honest
To heaven and my owne heart, and then if life
Will follow, it shall bee welcome.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Still perverse:
Stand forth my Leonora, looke upon her.

SP.SPEAKER: Bea.
SP.L: I see a comely frame which cannot bee
Without as faire a minde.

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.L: With her I make
Once more a tender of my wealth and thy
Enlargement.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: How can you discharge him, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.L: Take you no care for that, it shall be secur'd
If he accept, 'tis the last time of asking,
Answer to purpose now.

SP.SPEAKER: Bea.
SP.L: There shall neede none,
Sir, to forbid this marriage, but my selfe;
My resolution but warme before
Is now a flame I honour this faire Virgine,
And am too poore to thanke your love, but must not
Buy life with so much shame, I am Violante,
My last breath shall confirme it.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Beaumont thinke on't
A little better, be not mad; if this be possible
Embrace her instantlie.

SP.SPEAKER: Bea.
SP.L: Shee does not looke
With any countenance of love upon me:
See, shee does weepe.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Sheele love thee afterwards.
And shee doe not, she can but cuckold thee
There be more i'th Parish man.

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.L: Since you are so peremptory
So peremptory: here receave your sentence.
Live and love happilie.

SP.SPEAKER: Vio.
SP.L: My Dearest Beaumont.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: To what purpose is this? he must be hangd for Delamore.

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.L: Heer's one can cleere the danger.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: The Surgeon? did not you say he was dead?

SP.SPEAKER: Sur.
SP.L: I did, to serve his ends, which you see noble:
Delamore is past danger, but wants strength
To come abroad.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: You give me another life.

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.L: I see heaven has decreed him for thy husband,
And shat have my consent too.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: Now you blesse me.

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.L: I wished to call thee sonne, pardon my triall
Joy ever in your bosomes.

SP.SPEAKER: Bea.
SP.L: I feele a blessing
That onely can be thought, silence my tongue,
And let our hearts discourse.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Hazard, Penelope, Acre-lesse, Little-stocke, and Sel-away

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: You leave gentlefolks; who wishes joy.
And a bundle of boyes the first night?

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.L: Married.

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.L: Fast as the Priest could tie us.

SP.SPEAKER: A.S.L.
SP.L: We are witnesses.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Cozen two thousand pound, and Ladie now
Tis time to cleere all.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: I'le be divorc'd now
Wife y'are a Whore.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Ho there, no bug-words, come
Wee must tell something in your care. Be merry
You are no cuckold, make no noise, I know
That's it, offends your stomake.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: I touch'd not her, nor this with one rude action.
Weele talke the circumstance when you come home.
Your wife expected you, but when I came
She had prepar'd light, and her Cozen here
To have made you blush and chide you into honesty
Seeing their chast simplicities, was wonne
To silence, which brought on my better fortune.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: Can this be reall

SP.SPEAKER: Mi.
SP.L: By my hopes of peace
I'th tother World you have no injury:
My plot was onely to betraie you to
Love and repentance.

SP.SPEAKER: Pene.
SP.L: Be not troubled, sir,
I am a witnes of my Cozens truth,
And hope youle make all prosper, in renewing
Your faith to her.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Be wise and no more words
Thou hast a treasure in thy wife, make much on her:
For any act of mine, she is as chast
As when she was new borne. Love love her Jacke.
As when she was new borne. Love; love her Jacke.

SP.SPEAKER: Wi.
SP.L: I am asham'd, pray give me all forgivenes▪
I see my follies, heaven invites me gently
To thy chast bed, be thou againe my dearest,
Thy vertue shall instruct me: joy to all:
Here be more.—Delamore is living,
And Leonora mark'd to injoy him,
Violante is possest of Beaumont too.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: These be loves miracles: a spring tide flow
In every bosome.

SP.SPEAKER: Hu.
SP.L: This day let me feast you
Anon wee'le visit Delamore.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: My soule
Longs to salute him.

SP.SPEAKER: Ha.
SP.L: Here all follyes die.
May never Gamester have worse fate then I.
